item.description: Life does not offer its significance easily. Even less so when one is waiting expectantly- a moviego...
item.content:encoded:
Life does not offer its significance easily.
Even less so when one is waiting expectantly-
a moviegoer shocked into attention at the blare of a French horn.

No, Life is withholding of most of its greatness-
depending on the Liver to recognize and to appreciate.

Generous is a Songbird whose listener allows it to complete all four movements.
Spacious is a Tree Canopy when felt as a ceiling.
Staggering is a Skyward Plane charging down a relative line of parallel time.

There, words become heard.
There, they become moments.

There, a relief

From Here, the cacophony of isolated humanity constantly clamoring for response.
Never has so much of it been so alone.

We should all step outside to remember what it is like,
to not have to ask to live.

~~
@sagegibbons

He wears no mask, preferring his wild beard wrapped around his face like a bonnet.

Skin like leathery canvas and covered in ink so that the eye is more intrigued by its absence.

His boots are invincible. Their weight gives this urban oasis rural legitimacy.

He is more intimate with the fish than the jogging, biking, sailing masses who take warm silent satisfaction in recreating the Victorian ideal, but would never invite him to any environmental meeting. Too gruff. Too likely to vote Republican, if he was registered.

He pays no mind. Speaking only to the young fly fisher and those willing to nod their head as he strides by.

He brings the joint to his lips. A puff of white smoke floats into the clouds above. Moments later, he is gone.

But finally, here was a chance to leave all that behind for a life in the ‚Äúreal world‚Äù. The Company had set him up well. A fair reward for a lifetime in The Digital.

He brushed his hands over his suit, took a breath and strode into the room, quickly sitting down on the end of the sofa.

Trying to ignore the immensity beside him, he looked at her and remarked, ‚ÄúQuite a view, isn‚Äôt it?‚Äù

She smiled. They both looked away.

item.title: The churches all closed. Jets flying overhead. Lunatics banging pots and pans. Masked joggers, maske...
item.description: The churches all closed. Jets flying overhead. Lunatics banging pots and pans. Masked joggers, maske...
item.content:encoded:
The churches all closed. Jets flying overhead. Lunatics banging pots and pans. Masked joggers, masked pizza men, masked dogs awaiting testing; everyone in the park wearing masks; no one masked in a crowd of 30 watching the armored van roll over the discarded grass clippings. A woman beaten by a police officer (off duty, of course) for refusing to wear a mask in a warehouse store. A man spits in the face of a clerk. Alcohol sales increasing by 70 percent or more, and legal dope available for curbside pickup. Standoffs, the stockpiling of weapons, protests and counter-protests with assault rifles in state capitols. The hospitals not overwhelmed but empty and staff let go. Yellow murder tape across merry-go-rounds. Children, neighbors objects of medium-level suspicion at best. Technology not a stopgap or a substitute but a condition for a new conception of bare life. Packages on doorsteps, dropped by unseen and poorly remunerated agents of the world's richest man. Children raped on camera. Domestic assault. A hundred thousand defaults piling up in the portfolio of a single regional bank. Suicide. The end of education. The end of employment. Prophets, of course, everywhere.

Numbers will be sought to explain the world around us. What does it mean to say that the present crisis is somehow twice as bad as that of 2008, that a fifth of the country is out of work, that the only industry now hiring is debt collection?

Was all of this inevitable? Is it now? It is always possible to insist that we should seek another way, a path of shared work, shared purpose, and shared wealth, as our great-grandparents did long ago.

But this is naive.
_____
@joe_delvicario

item.description:

item.content:encoded:
A Whale Tale
__________

I visited an old friend at her new bartending gig. The bar looked newly renovated, maybe the post-Sandy insurance covered the imported Swedish floors. The bar was called the Whales Tale.
I was a terrible conversationalist that night. All I thought about was eyes and whales. Melville wrote in Moby Dick, "For what is it that makes the front of a man-- what, indeed, but his eyes?" Okay, sure. But what do whale eyes look like? So I looked it up, dead smack in the middle of a whirlpool on the dancefloor which kept dragging me deeper into an abyss of uncoordinated side-stepping. ("A whale sees in monochrome and has one eye on each side of its head.") Soon after, on the bathroom line pacing with excretive excitement as the thought of seeing fluids all over the toilet seat disgusted me, I finally understood that I was fighting a losing battle. The plethora of characters, events, dates, and the infinite branching of cause and effect in my life has strained my emotional capacity to love my neighbors. I find myself banging my head against the wall of history and looking up and seeing, growing all over the world - ever higher and denser like creeping ivy, the total descent into meaninglessness. At this point, I was spinning. It's hard to stay sober in an environment where everybody hates everybody way deep down. Where does this hatred come from? Lust? Then I saw the blue-eyed chick.
She was bobbing drunkenly side-to-side between three burned pieces of toast showered in cologne who I, unfortunately, need to still call human beings although they were the bastard children of consumerism. They reminded me of Ed, Edd, and Eddy if it took place in Howard Beach.

She had her phone in her hand the whole time, and anyone who dances with their phone in their hand does not actually want to be there. What she really wanted was a break from yet after another day in a seemingly futureless life. But bars did not make it this long by being beacons of introspection.
_______

Below Teddy
__________
No one quite understood why they were there. But they came out anyway. Two of the finest legs Western Civilization could produce, all wrapped up in a hot-pink sweat factory skirt, approached a young boy. A whiff of Hani Mori consumed his nostrils and he thought he was mature to realize ‚Äúthat‚Äù was a woman: legs, perfume, and a distraction from reality. Up until this moment, the only olfactory sensation with equal power had been mom's chocolate chip cookies.
The pink-haired, non-gendered NYU student holding up a sign which read ‚ÄúWe demand justice!‚Äù once heard a feminist semiologist deliver a talk on the synecdoche of the chocolate chip cookie. Cautious not to attach a gendered dimension to the raw ball of sugar, the semiologist declared that chocolate chip cookies must be understood as a heuristic of patriarchy, a ploy and satire of femininity only a pig like Bukowski could imagine. The oven is a harem, a simulacrum of a brothel where these raw balls of artificial social constructions are transfigured like the Eucharist into a product of capitalism where the natural, rawest roots of all matter become manicured into archetypes imbued with domesticity and male lust which fuels the imperialist U.S. military-industrial complex. In short, the wife should not engage in next Fall's bake sale.
He coughed a bit as the woman passed and he imagined that he coughed like his brother does when he smokes his Spirits in the backyard and tells him to keep quiet about it. His dad looked down at him and saw where his son's attention was. Finding a profoundly evolutionary comfort in knowing the family lineage of masculinity is in good hands, he patted him on the shoulder and grinned.
The frizzy-haired lady next to them saw this whole encounter unfold. She would have scoffed aloud but her eyes said it all. Hand on hip and mouth slightly agape, she likened the father's juvenile approval of his son's pubescent sexual curiosity to her ex-husband. Last she heard, he was holding hands with a blondie down in South Beach with too many buttons undone. She always told him to button-up, since it looked uncouth and mafioso. No wonder he left.
_______
@joe_delvicario

Here I stand,
midst the stereoscopic embrace
of the neighborhood gust of wind
Gently caressing the stunted
Canopy
Of this forest, pressed down
by the salt air of the sea.

A media of outrage is incapable
of producing such a sensation

That can be felt,
yet only recognized
with humble grace.

This eden of slow time
Asks me
To not think so much. ‚Äî
@sagegibbons

item.title: One of the many effects of the Covid-19 pandemic has been a surge in online visitors to museum colle...
item.description: One of the many effects of the Covid-19 pandemic has been a surge in online visitors to museum colle...
item.content:encoded:
One of the many effects of the Covid-19 pandemic has been a surge in online visitors to museum collections. This, in turn, has sparked renewed interest in the notion of ‚Äòvirtual museums‚Äô, and one name that crops up frequently in this context is the 20th Century French writer and politician AndreÃÅ Malraux, inventor of the term museÃÅe imaginaire ‚Äì usually translated as the ‚Äòmuseum without walls‚Äô, or the ‚Äòimaginary museum.‚Äô What I have gathered from Malraux‚Äôs writings is that the museum is the product of the globalized, secular West. Malraux sought for a way to synthesize the individual, who in his mind was (and still is) increasingly conceived of as an amalgam of social constructions, to a unity in world culture not rooted in the Christian Absolute (e.g., Steve Bannon‚Äôs Judeo-Christian Civilization). In typical post-war French existentialist fashion, he thought humans possessed a mechanism to self-create meaning which negates the nothingness of the self by possessing images and ideas of meaning.
Because the modern age has lost a sense of a human orientation to the Absolute, the transcendent is now a wholly negative idea to people who believe humans create their purpose. The results appear to be spiritual suffering and a trailing obsession to fill this existential void. Art, Malraux claims, is the dominant form of action in response to this transcendent absence. Humans seek to triumph over death by the power of creation.
So, what do the museums make of this modern condition? They open their doors to all, showcasing the works of artists who once believed all art was a testament to transcendent religious goals and other artists who see art as Malraux did. Art is the individual‚Äôs fight against tradition, with imposed hierarchies, with unwavering beliefs, with closed-door institutions, and, penultimately, death.
Museums are the churches we used to attend. Where we worshiped, prayed, and suffered alongside strangers who we called our brothers and sisters. Now, we attend these new churches as intellectual invitees, hoping to establish a connection with art removed of all context and transcendent meaning. Just like us.
________

item.title: Varying images come to mind when people hear the term ‚ÄúArtificial Intelligence.‚Äù Some see IBM's Wats...
item.description: Varying images come to mind when people hear the term ‚ÄúArtificial Intelligence.‚Äù Some see IBM's Wats...
item.content:encoded:
Varying images come to mind when people hear the term ‚ÄúArtificial Intelligence.‚Äù Some see IBM's Watson defeating the world's best human players in Jeopardy! Others see Google¬† Deepmind's AlphaGo dethroning the world's best Go player. Some imagine Schwarzenegger's Terminator. Watson and AlphaGo are examples of narrow super-intelligence, possessing capabilities superior to the most capable humans, but only in an limited domain, thus posing no danger to us. The Terminator, albeit entertaining, is good old-fashioned Hollywood sensationalism. Consequently, it is difficult to marshal an appropriate emotional response to the dangers posed by AI that is both super-intelligent, and possesses the cross-domain abilities that human-level ‚Äògeneral intelligence‚Äô allows.

Nick Bostrom, director of The Future of Humanity Institute at Oxford University, and author of ‚ÄúSuperintelligence,‚Äù argues that, by the turn of the century, it is likely that we will develop some form of AI that surpasses humans in 'general intelligence' (the ability to perform any task as well as any adult human). As a result, the spectrum of intelligence will extend far beyond what is achievable by the human brain. By the nature of physics, electronic circuits operate 1,000,000 times faster than biochemical ones. This means that an AI with ‚Äògeneral intelligence‚Äô no greater than that of any current human, could perform 20,000 years of intellectual work in the matter of one week. One can see how powerful a technology like this would be, whether we would be able to maintain control over it or not. This is not to say that existential catastrophe is the default outcome, but it is paramount that we proceed with caution.

This technology seems so foreign, so sci-fi, so far in the future, that the concerned cries of the few fall on deaf ears. Yet, the frontier of super-intelligence is here; now is the time to make sure it is something we can live with.
___________

item.content:encoded:
A few nights ago, I finished Alberto Moravia‚Äôs ‚ÄùAgostino‚Äù and I have a few final thoughts on this novella.
This is not your typical coming-of-age story. Agostino, a coddled and chaste 13-year-old, adores his widowed mother and her ‚Äúbeloved body‚Äù with the shamelessness of a child who has just begun to recognize people as sexual beings. His reverence towards his mother is shaken when a young, charming boatman joins them on their daily ‚Äùpatino‚Äù (Italian: bathing raft) rides out to sea. To quiet the rampant thoughts about his mother and this novel male archetype, Agostino deliberately embarks on a journey of adolescent freedom with a group of poor neighborhood boys who have an appetite for debauchery, nicotine, and adult acceptance.
____________

Adolescence‚Äîwith its mood swings and blindsiding first loves‚Äîis a period of hyper-feeling without catharsis or reprieve. Many of Moravia‚Äôs protagonists, young and old, share this adolescent quality, trying relentlessly to understand what they cannot. Moravia creates this discordance on the page, and it is just enthralling.
I am no longer the young son of a single mother, but I know those Moravian moments of adolescent intrigue driven by the transformation of filial love into sensual appetite all too well. This discord is the debonding all mothers curse and what all boys fight for.
@joe_delvicario

item.content:encoded:
He detested jazz and everything about popular culture; he had no affection for the landscape at all; he remained studiously mandarin in his ways; smoke pillars and anodyne brick homes was his preferred aesthetic; and therefore, because he was brought up in a Marxist-Hegelian philosophical tradition that taught him to despise anything resembling those barbaric, traitorous stilyagi who ruined a generation of Russian literature and opera, everything about the worldwide influence of American films, industry, habits of daily life, fact-based learning, and pragmatism irked him. This was my unlikely companion aboard a 12:15 p.m. train from New York City to Poughkeepsie. His name was Jacoby.

We spoke of worldly affairs, far removed and too esoteric for the woman next to me scribbling away at her Sudoku and the kid a few rows up whose foot bobbed up-and-down ferociously as he sipped his iced coffee.
He was a psychoanalyst for most of his adult life. I appreciated how he explained things as if I was his grandson. His advice was told through mediums of story and photography. Psychoanalysis met the need for emotional adjustment resulting from accelerated social change at the turn of the twentieth century. Jacoby was captivated by the depths of the human mind, especially during his walks through Washington Square Park with Alvin Toffler during his undergraduate years at NYU.

item.description: In his 1987 book, Crisis and Leviathan, Robert Higgs argued that crises best explain why and how the...
item.content:encoded:
In his 1987 book, Crisis and Leviathan, Robert Higgs argued that crises best explain why and how the state power continues to grow. It was the Depression, two world wars, and the Cold War that bulked up Uncle Sam. Once bulked up, Uncle Sam never shrunk.
Uncle Sam is said to be our guardian from the state of nature, which Hobbes famously described in Leviathan as ‚Äúsolitary, poor, nasty, brutish, and short.‚Äù He continued: During the time men live without a common power to keep them in awe, they are in that condition which is called war; and stuck a war, as is of every man, against every man.‚Äù The state is the conqueror of nature, the greatest domesticator.
How will the state grow after the coronavirus? Only time will tell, but what I do know is that the state will continue its crusade against the ‚Äúshortness‚Äù of nature; in other words, death.
As a society grows richer, so does its appetite for life. Death in the West is a technical failure, not an end to a metaphysical journey. Every cause of death is curable, if only we listen to the scientists more. So they say.
The effect of this unprecedented, global moment will be Uncle Sam‚Äôs crusade against death. The state will try to monitor our movements, both public and private. The state will monitor virus chatter just as intelligence agencies monitor chatter for terrorist activity. The state will do almost anything for the sake of the preservation of life, and we will accept it.
We will accept it because once we emerge all bleary-eyed from the isolation wards we once called our homes, we will feel a deep unease that ‚Äúthey‚Äù did not keep us safe. A new populism is brewing, a populism for life above all else, no matter the costs.
Uncle Sam is taking notes.
___________
@joe_delvicario

During the 1998 trial of Ramzi Yousef for his involvement in the 1993 World Trade Center bombing, SDNY Judge Kevin Duffy addressed Yousef from the bench with these powerful words: ‚ÄúRamzi Yousef, you claim to be an Islamic militant. Of all the persons killed or harmed in some way by the World Trade Center bomb, you cannot name one who was against you or your cause. You did not care, just so long as you left dead bodies and people hurt.

Ramzi Yousef, you are not fit to uphold Islam. Your God is death. Your God is not Allah ... You weren't seeking conversions. The only thing you wanted to do was to cause death. Your God is not Allah. You worship death and destruction. What you do, you do not for Allah; you do it only to satisfy your own twisted sense of ego.

You would have others believe that you are a soldier, but the attacks on civilization for which you stand convicted here were sneak attacks which sought to kill and maim totally innocent people ... You, Ramzi Yousef, came to this country pretending to be an Islamic fundamentalist, but you cared little or nothing for Islam or the faith of the Muslims. Rather, you adored not Allah, but the evil that you yourself have become. And I must say that as an apostle of evil, you have been most effective.‚Äù Judge Duffy, a Catholic, a graduate of Fordham Law, a father, and an esteemed judge, passed away on Wednesday from the coronavirus.
Stay healthy everyone. You are all on our minds.

item.title: I miss our talks. Underlying them was a thirst for unity. There was something Biblical about our ta...
item.description: I miss our talks. Underlying them was a thirst for unity. There was something Biblical about our ta...
item.content:encoded:
I miss our talks.
Underlying them was a thirst for unity. There was something Biblical about our talks. Two imperfect humans pleading for our sins to be absolved. You once told me only children and fools tell the truth. But you never told me why. You once told me that originality is unintentional, and probably regrettable. But you never told me why.

I went to the pond today where we always spoke. I saw a woman with surgical gloves and a cigarette between her fingers. I thought it was such a strange combination of precaution and nonchalance. But if you were there, you would have pointed out that sex is also a strange combination of precaution and nonchalance. Your facetiousness is missed. Facetiousness is mistaken for uncouth immaturity. But truth is revealed in what we are told not to laugh at.
A newborn in his mother‚Äôs arms stared at the pond. I remembered how you once described me when I was a newborn. Dirty, but marvelous. Infinite in possibility, capable of the miracle of growth. This bundle of delicate porcelain and biological perfection will come to know love, anxiety, prayer, suffering, metaphysics, and death. Trapped in the womb for months, the newborn is compelled to breath but it hurts. Compelled to see light, but it blinds. Compelled to hear noise, but it terrifies. A newborn learns that nature is adversarial and the mother is nurturing and mitigating. The gulf between the pond and his mother‚Äôs arms is his unconscious training of this axiom.
You are old, retired from this world of theatrics. Now you are afloat in the world of geriatrics. Every old man is a confession, a revelation of truth. You were was once a madman. Your wrinkles show a life of effort trying to unite yourself to the world.

I miss our talks, the only time we confessed and concealed truth for the sake of unity.
__________________

The tragedy is assumed to have played a role in the US financial panic of 1857, which resulted from a declining international economy and an over expansion of the domestic economy.

Over a century later the ship and its gold were located by a now very rich team who made use of Bayesian probability.

Andy Warhol is called many names, but rarely is he called Ruthenian. A Ruthenian is a member of the Byzantine Catholic Church whose origins lie in the former Austro-Hungarian Empire and are now in modern-day Ukraine.
At Warhol‚Äôs funeral, John Richardson delivered a eulogy for his life-long friend and spoke of Warhol‚Äôs ‚Äúsecret piety‚Äù, which ‚Äúinevitably changes our perception of an artist who fooled the world into believing his only obsessions were money, fame, and glamour, and that he was cool to the point of callousness. Never take Andy at face value.‚Äù There‚Äôs much literature out there for you to find on Warhol‚Äôs secret piety, such as the fact that he nearly always carried a rosary and small missal in his pocket and he put his nephew through the seminary.
What I hope to leave you with is a fresh perspective on who Warhol was and what he aimed to achieve with his art. Warhol was surely influenced by Schluckbildchen, which means ‚Äúdevotional pictures for swallowing.‚Äù These small notes of paper had sacred images on them with the purpose of being swallowed since it was believed that the papers possessed curative powers.

Warhol portrayed twentieth-century society‚Äôs hunger for new curative powers based on socially accepted norms of artificial meaning. Celebrities and media entertainment became our priests and dogma. Consumerism supplanted all tradition, all authority. The deeply religious nature of Warhol‚Äôs art is neither well-known nor widely accepted as an accurate interpretation of his life‚Äôs work.
Warhol, only once, betrayed his ‚Äúsecret piety‚Äù, so to speak. In the final image, we see him with Pope John Paul II. For once, he looks like a person, not a symbol or a caricature but a Ruthenian.
@joe_delvicario

item.content:encoded:
‚ÄúIS A‚Äù vs ‚ÄúHAS A‚Äù and What Happens to Identity When Machines Replace Human Labor

If a Lamborghini can play an FM broadcast through its speaker, you could technically find out that by some definition, the Lamborghini is a radio.

That seems absurd. It makes more sense to say that the Lamborghini has a radio, just the way it has tires or a transmission.

@ericrweinstein conjectures that we make this error when talking about workers.
For example we say that someone IS a doctor, or a dishwasher... and instead, what we need to do as the value of human labor decreases, is to readjust our model of an economic agent from an ‚Äúis a‚Äù to ‚Äúhas a‚Äù model.

The idea being that you, (like the Lamborghini) may have a radio, but you are not a radio. And that when radios become obsolete, the identity of the Lamborghini is not harmed...The economic translation being that you may consist of a breadwinner, a contributor, and a consumer, so that when the breadwinner part of your identity is rendered obsolete by A.I., you still have your identity, and with it, a meaningful life in the next stage of a 21st or 22nd century economy. ( @matthewzehnbauer )

item.content:encoded:
On Christmas Eve half a century ago, Cardinals outfielder Curt Flood mailed a letter that changed professional sports forever.
At the end of the 1969 season, Flood had just won his seventh consecutive Gold Glove award with the Cardinals. A three-time All-Star, he had a career batting average of .293 and was two years removed from batting .335. On Oct. 7, 1969, he and Tim McCarver were traded to Philadelphia as part of an eight-player deal that also included Dick Allen.

Flood refused to go.
What‚Äôs been called the MLB‚Äôs ‚ÄúDeclaration of Independence,‚Äù Flood‚Äôs rejection letter began by stating: ‚ÄúAfter twelve years in the Major Leagues, I do not feel that I am a piece of property to be bought and sold irrespective of my wishes.‚Äù Flood‚Äôs rejection of a trade to the Phillies ignited the labor relations revolution that cost him his career. Between addressing commissioner Bowie Kuhn and signing his name, in an economical 127 words, Flood launched what would help create the billion-dollar free agency market that dominates not only baseball but seemingly all professional sports.

Flood‚Äôs letter challenged the then-authoritative reserve clause which, in North American professional sports, was part of a player‚Äôs contract which stated the rights to players were retained by the team upon the contract's expiration. Players under these contracts were not free to enter into another contract with another team. Once signed to a contract, players could, at the team's whim, be reassigned, traded, sold, or released. In 1975, after much-heated litigation, Flood and other players who brought suits against their parent organizations prevailed and the reserve clause was abolished in favor of free agency.
At last week‚Äôs news conference to introduce himself and his record $324 million contract with the Yankees, Gerrit Cole named-dropped Flood. ‚ÄúChallenging the reserve clause was essential to the blossoming sport we have today,‚Äù Cole said, later explaining to New York reporters how a teammate would challenge players to know their history. ‚ÄúI hope everyone has that conversation about Curt Flood on the bus.
@joe_delvicario

It is well-known that da Vinci housed only young, attractive men in his home as their master where he catalogued rather strangely and meticulously how much he spent on them and their rivalries for his attention. Then there was the time he was accused of sodomy with a male as a young man. Wouldn't you be as prudent as possible with your sex life if you were accused of a crime that at the time carried prison sentences and death in some circumstances?
In Part II, we have the sketch of Leonardo‚Äôs closest pupil, Salai, with his hand gestured towards the sky which was a common artistic device in the Renaissance to symbolize a higher implicit ideal. Then, we have the erect penis also pointing upwards. Can we interpret this sketch as da Vinci‚Äôs acceptance of his homosexuality and a declaration of the natural beauty and truth of human sexuality in the age of humanism?
We definitely can, and we definitely should.

item.content:encoded:
Part IV | @joe_delvicario
____________ "Now we understand why Leonardo assigned the memory of his supposed experience with the vulture to his suckling period. What the phantasy conceals is merely a reminiscence of sucking‚Äî or being suckled‚Äîat his mother‚Äôs breast, a scene of human beauty that he, like so many artists, undertook to depict with his brush, in the guise of the mother of God and her child." So how do we go from active to passive sucking?

Freud continues on page 48: "The child‚Äôs love for his mother cannot continue to develop consciously any further; it succumbs to repression. The boy represses his love for his mother: he puts himself in her place, identifies himself with her, and takes his own person as a model in whose likeness he chooses the new objects of his love. In this way he has become a homosexual. What he has in fact done is to slip back to auto-erotism: for the boys whom he now loves as he grows up are after all only substitutive figures and revivals of himself in childhood‚Äîboys whom he loves in the way in which his mother loved him when he was a child. He finds the objects of his love along the path of narcissism, as we say; for Narcissus, according to the Greek legend, was a youth who preferred his own reflection to everything else and who was changed into the lovely flower of that name. [‚Ä¶] By repressing his love for his mother he preserves it in his unconscious and from now on remains faithful to her. While he seems to pursue boys and to be their lover, he is in reality running away from the other women, who might cause him to be unfaithful." Freud concludes that we cannot expect to find in Leonardo anything more than traces of untransformed sexual inclination. But, to take a firm stance, Freud followed that these traces "pointed in one direction and moreover allow him to be reckoned as a homosexual (p. 50)."

item.title:
Part II | @joe_delvicario ______________
The "third type" of Freud's three types of infantile sex...
item.description:
Part II | @joe_delvicario ______________
The "third type" of Freud's three types of infantile sex...
item.content:encoded:
Part II | @joe_delvicario
______________

The "third type" of Freud's three types of infantile sexual research was the "rarest and most perfect" kind. Here, the libido evades the fate of repression by being sublimated from the very beginning into curiosity and by becoming attached to the powerful instinct for research as a reinforcement. With second types, intellectual development may be able to resist repression, but natural investigation often manifests in sexual activity.

Freud asserts on the next page, with a justifiable element of hesitation: "The core of his nature, and the secret of it, would appear to be that after his curiosity had been activated in infancy in the service of sexual interests he succeeded in sublimating the greater part of his libido into an urge for research." Freud bases his defense of his assertion on an interpretation of a recurring early childhood memory of da Vinci. Da Vinci described the vulture memory as follows: "It seems that I was always destined to be so deeply concerned with vultures; for I recall as one of my very earliest memories that while I was in my cradle a vulture came down to me, and opened my mouth with its tail, and struck me many times with its tail against my lips." Freud considered the negligent disregard of this childhood vignette by biographers over the centuries an egregious injustice akin to rejecting "the body of legends, traditions and interpretations found in a nation‚Äôs early history." I love this last note. History is a recurring dream in constant interpretation. Whatever we think happened in our past, no matter how fuzzy or close to the truth our recollection is,¬† are priceless pieces of evidence of individual mental development, just like nations.

Freud‚Äôs interpretation: "If we examine with the eyes of a psycho-analyst Leonardo‚Äôs phantasy of the vulture, it does not appear strange for long. We seem to recall having come across the same sort of thing in many places, for example in dreams; so that we may venture to translate the phantasy from its own special language into words that are generally understood. The translation is then seen to point to an erotic content.‚Äù

Part I | @joe_delvicario __________________
Still an apprentice and living in the house of his ma...
item.description:
Part I | @joe_delvicario __________________
Still an apprentice and living in the house of his ma...
item.content:encoded:
Part I | @joe_delvicario
__________________

Still an apprentice and living in the house of his master Verrocchio, a young Leonardo da Vinci was charged with forbidden homosexual practices, along with some other contemporaries living in Verrocchio's home. The charge ended in an acquittal.

Three centuries later, Sigmund Freud took it upon himself to explore the deeply personal and, some might say, scandalous history of da Vinci's homosexuality. The result we now have of Freud's unique psychoanalytic inquiry is his 1910 work, Leonardo da Vinci: A Memory of His Childhood.

Freud devotes particular attention to a beautiful aphorism said to be uttered by da Vinci: "Nessuna cosa si pu√≤ amare n√® odiare, se prima non si ha cognition di quella" (Nothing you can love nor hate, if before you have no cognition of that). His word's surely inspired action, as attested by his voluminous manuscripts on science and the blossoming humanist philosophies of his time, his inventions, and of course, his paintings. But for a man with such an enviable dual nature as scientific investigator and artist, why did he barely investigate his sexuality? Da Vinci never married, and no sexual relations with women have surfaced in the centuries of biographies on his life.
Why is this?

On page 22, Freud states: "Leonardo teaches us how many other things we have to take into account in connection with these [sexual conversion] processes. The postponement of loving until full knowledge is acquired ends in a substitution of the latter for the former. [‚Ä¶] He has investigated instead of loving. And that is perhaps why Leonardo‚Äôs life was so much poorer in love than that of other great men, and of other artists. The stormy passions of a nature that inspires and consumes, passions in which other men have enjoyed their richest experience, appear not to have touched him." He follows: ‚ÄùIf we reflect on the concurrence in Leonardo of his over powerful instinct for research and the atrophy of his sexual life (which was restricted to what is called ideal [sublimated] homosexuality) we shall be disposed to claim him as a model instance of our third type."

item.content:encoded:
I can't get this image out of my mind.
One day, the Lincoln Memorial will be a ruin visited by citizens of a new civilization. History has not proven otherwise. While the Lincoln Memorial was being built, it‚Äôs unlikely the architects and sculptors imagined the site would become a tourist site of the Ancient American civilization.
In 1889, John A. Mitchell imagined such a fate for his beloved nation in the novel, The Last American.
The story begins in 2951 aboard Persian captain Khan-Li‚Äôs exploration vessel. Khan was inspired to set sail and find the land of Mehrika (America) after reading the classic, ‚ÄúHistory of the Mehrikans.‚Äù In 1990, the Mehrikan civilization ceased to exist due to the disastrous effects of climate change and greed (üòÖ). The book progresses energetically towards a very bleak ending (I won‚Äôt spoil it!). The Last American is an absolute treasure. I consider it the most cherished book on my bookshelf. I love the funny names of the Persians: Prince of Dimph-Yoo-Chur (Dim Future), Fattan-laiz-eh (Fat and Lazy), and Ja-Khaz (Jack Ass). I love the etchings of America in ruins. The etchings depict the entropy that currently exists as the shadow of all progress. The innovation we will create and experience in our lifetime will one day be a footnote in the long list of humanity‚Äôs achievements. Widely cited, but forever a memory.
Mitchell included a scene where the explorers decide a wooden Native American figure holding tobacco was the Mehrikan‚Äôs God. This exchange critiqued the 19th-century excavation craze that took place in Europe and America and our flawed omniscience of the past. This scene only furthers my point.
Our civilization will be interpreted, dissected, critiqued, laughed at, reified, reimagined, and then, just like Mitchell and his fantasy novel, forgotten.
@joe_delvicario

A Gizmodo.com article about this photo says our feathered friend here was singing to ‚Äúdefend its territory‚Äù. I‚Äôm gonna call an audible on this one and say thats most likely incorrect.

For one, it‚Äôs mid-March. These guys are the die hards. The ones who stayed. A hardy bunch of stubborn blue blooded North Americans like the rest of us. They‚Äôve been settled into their little claim of wetland for quite some time now. Probably since late August. There are no challengers. No threat. Just the cutting stillness of late Winter air.

Secondly, his body language. When male Red-winged Blackbirds display to defend and define their territory, they stretch their wings, sometimes tilt forward a bit, and cry out their signature multi-octave whoop. This guy is cool as a cucumber, just whistling a familiar tune and pumping out a vapor ring or two. Light work. Literally.‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚ÄîAnyhow. Take a look at that map in the second image a little closer. If you‚Äôre in the purple, you‚Äôve got red-winged blackbirds with you all year. Orange is just during the breeding months (i.e. spring/summer) and blue is a special area where they don‚Äôt breed at all. For some reason. Go figure.

Do me a favor and find a little nature spot by some pond or lake or wetland. Keep an eye out for these guys tucked into some vegetation that has good sight lines on the water‚Äôs edge. Cattails are usually a guarantee. If you find one or twelve, DM us about it. We read everything. üåøüåøüåø

What an amazing tweet.
First, let‚Äôs revisit April 1945.
On the 12th, President Roosevelt dies.
On the 14th, General Eisenhower makes the most unpopular decision of his military career.
With nearly two million Allied soldiers ready to cross the Elbe and proceed to Berlin, Eisenhower orders them to halt.
HALT?
Churchill is apoplectic.
Stalin is ecstatic.
Hitler is suicidal.
Truman is content.
The Americans agreed with the Soviet Union at Tehran and Yalta to divide Berlin into spheres of jurisdiction once the city was captured. At the Elbe, American troops were already too deep into the agreed-upon de jure Soviet jurisdiction, and Eisenhower did not want to risk an estimated 100,000 men to take control of land he would have to concede over to the Soviets once the war ended.
Why is this important?
Well, by the 25th, American and Soviet troops met at the Elbe and celebrated their monumental conquest of Germany. A few years later, this river became the marker of a new conflict: the Cold War.
_____
In 1965, Charles de Gaulle offered a vision which would thaw a globe frosted over by two decades of conflict between the U.S. and U.S.S.R.
General de Gaulle announced the ‚ÄùOne Europe‚Äù vision. One Europe would extend from ‚Äùthe Atlantic to the Urals,‚Äù embracing not merely the countries of the European Common Market, but those of the European Free Trade Association and the Communist lands of the Warsaw Pact.
De Gaulle distanced himself from the American and Soviet conflict, a conflict he always considered ahistorical and unwise.
De Gaulle pulled France out of NATO and began to negotiate with the Soviets on France‚Äôs terms.
With no more cowboys in the White House barking orders at de Gaulle, he signaled a new global balance of power which extended Europe‚Äôs influence from Western Europe to the Ural Mountains in Russia. Here, the Urals symbolically replaced the Elbe.
The Urals are considered the border between ‚ÄúEuropean‚Äù Russia and ‚ÄùAsian‚Äù Russia. With Macron sliding in the polls and the Gilet Jaunes still waging their protests, he is taking France an unusual step backward to move Europe forward.
Macron the Gaullist? Who knew!

Two days ago marked the solemn fourth anniversary of Khaled Al-Assad‚Äôs murder and the destruction of Palmyra by the Islamic State (ISIL). Khaled‚Äôs murder is painful to revisit. I remember the headlines coming out in 2014-2015 of ISIL‚Äôs horrendous crimes: Jame‚Äôs Foley‚Äôs beheading, the heads of Shiites lining the streets of Raqqa, the genocide of the Yazidis. It was all becoming unbearable to keep up with from my lofty distance here in America. Then came Khaled's murder.
Khaled was 83 when ISIL entered Palmyra. He was the director of the ancient city‚Äôs Antiques archive whose historical depth and meticulous safekeeping codified Palmyra as a UNESCO World Heritage Site. In anticipation of the Islamic State‚Äôs looting, he hid the most precious artifacts in a spot whose whereabouts were known only to him. When ISIL entered the city, they ordered Khaled to reveal the archive to them, and for his compliance, they would spare him a gruesome death.
Khaled read the news just like I did. He knew ISIL rarely kept prisoners, especially the elderly whose ages hindered them from accepting the legitimacy of an infantile government. Khaled refused, despite the advice from family and colleagues to comply.
Around noon on Sunday, four year ago, Khaled was beheaded publically in the ancient city‚Äôs square. The NYT reported the following day: ‚ÄùAfter detaining him for weeks, the jihadists dragged him on Tuesday to a public square where a masked swordsman cut off his head in front of a crowd, Mr. Asaad's relatives said. His blood-soaked body was then suspended with red twine by its wrists from a traffic light, his head resting on the ground between his feet, his glasses still on, [...].‚Äù ISIL, in the fashion of the Mongols, made an example of Palmyra by reducing the city to rubble.
This year, the artifacts hidden by Khaled have begun to be showcased in museums in Syria for the first time since 2015.
Thanks to Khaled‚Äôs heroism, we can still marvel the treasures of history and the power of the human will.

Sam Harris is an American author, philosopher and neuroscientist who touches topics like free will and ethics, the relationship between science and morality, meditation and the phenomenology of religious experiences, politics, religion, religious extremism, and dogmatism.
Today we‚Äôll talk about his views on free will and what makes them different from others.
Plenty of philosophers have argued against the existence of free will. Often, they start with the ‚Äòfact‚Äô that humans experience free will first hand, and continue by doing their best to make this experience compatible with a consistent view of the world. The standard argument is to point out that there is just matter and motion, and that this state of the universe, including your brain, mind and soul if there is such a thing, is the product of an ocean of prior causes, none of which were ultimately caused or controlled by you. Your brain, environment, genetics, thoughts and actions are all caused by phenomena completely outside of your control so where‚Äôs the free will? @SamHarrisOrg, who has spent long periods studying meditation with renowned masters around the world, argues and in fact demonstrates in his meditation app ‚ÄòWaking Up‚Äô, that the first person experience of free will isn‚Äôt even there when you look for it. That is, the problem that philosophers have been grappling with for centuries is in fact an illusory one.

To follow up on this week‚Äôs #PhilosophyMonday check out #SamHarris ‚Äòs work on free will and tell us what you think! Do we have free will? Do we experience it? Does free will change how we view ethics? [ @matthewzehnbauer ]

item.content:encoded:
In the 150 years since Darwin‚Äôs Theory of Evolution, six generations (!) of Intellectuals have been desperately clawing at the question of language. ‚ÄúWhat Is It?‚Äù writes Noam Chomsky, sixty years after he became immortal for apparently settling that very same question with his assertion of a Universal Grammer delivered by a soon-to-be-discovered Language Organ. In Kingdom of Speech, Tom Wolfe demonstrates painfully and gleefully how much time can be wasted falling in line with the crowd piously fighting for their leader. How much of our great intellectual pursuits can amount to pettiness!

I agree entirely. Path dependency of thought is an ever-tempting mistress. What originality is left in a graduate student‚Äôs brain after indoctrinating themself with the greats of their field? I would say none, but I have a source of optimism: Theory. Theory is the wellspring of discovery. It is only through theory that we can ever hope to anchor our explorations to reality.

Wolfe concludes that language put a halt to evolution, and that speech is the source of the spade, the dance, the iPhone, the religion, the social class. All these created by our emergent wit. Perhaps. But I am quite positive that he is misguided. These things are all evolutionary, just not strictly biological. They are cultural.
Cultural evolution is the term- still widely unknown to most, including the late Tom Wolfe.

When we learn from the most successful or the most self-similar, we are mechanizing an adaptive process. The same for when we correct and update our inherited cultural information by interaction with the people around us. These automatic inheritance behaviors are responsible for the cultural innovations of our species, language included. Wolfe is right to say that if you remove language, you lose everything that makes us, us. But he is wrong in concluding that language is somehow removed from the same chain of causation that created our hominid line. Rather, it just accelerated our distinction.

Wolfe never got there, but you can. Look up Joe Henrich. Oh no, I‚Äôm doing it too! Charisma triumphs! Or is it Theory? You decide.
@sagegibbons

This frieze from Fulton County, Georgia shows "Medicine's battle with Death." Note the rod with two snakes. Many mistake it for the Rod of Asclepius, the traditional symbol of healing. This rod is, in fact, the Caduceus, the symbol of commerce and Hermes, the Greek god of merchants, thieves, trickery, travelers, and sports.
________

Now knowing what the Caduceus represents, do you see any issues with this symbol‚Äôs use in the medical field?

Quoting Stuart Tyson in the Scientific Monthly: ‚ÄùAs god of the high-road and the market-place Hermes was perhaps above all else the patron of commerce and the fat purse: as a corollary, he was the special protector of the traveling salesman. As spokesman for the gods, he not only brought peace on earth (occasionally even the peace of death), but his silver-tongued eloquence could always make the worse appear the better cause. From this latter point of view, would not his symbol be suitable for certain Congressmen, all medical quacks, book agents and purveyors of vacuum cleaners, rather than for the straight-thinking, straight-speaking therapeutist?‚Äù _______

What do you think? Is Tyson melodramatic, or does he have a point?

I tag, therefore I am. ‚ÄúGraffiti and tagging is a unique form for declaring an imaged ‚ÄòI‚Äô in an age of incessant and often meaningless change.¬† The graffitist can express individualism and gain permanence through a discourse that features uniquely created images.‚Äù [1]

Graffiti is a form of human communication and can offer valuable insight on its respective society.¬† Governments have taken various approaches in dealing with the issue of graffiti vandalism, such as zero-tolerance policies and labeling graffiti as a subculture with a more progressive and liberal mindset.¬† To me, graffiti reflects nuances of a society that may otherwise be left unknown, and offers a universal means of activism.

Friedrich Nietzsche argues that the motivation behind graffiti is, ‚ÄúThe Power of ‚ÄòI.‚Äô‚Äù¬†In any given society, the well-off and accepted individuals of the upper classes do not have pressing incentives to spray paint their name, artwork, or political ideology on another individual‚Äôs property.¬†Graffiti‚Äôs raw and extreme nature allows for a level of power and longevity that is exponentially more difficult to achieve through verbal speech or written words.
Grafitti is meant to be seen by the public. Place, style, and purpose guide the graffiti artist‚Äôs strokes and sprays.
Does graffiti inherently indicate the demise of a society? Do names, statements, and images painted illegally on the sides of buildings, train cars, street signs, etc., merely reflect a crumbling, problematic community, or does it inspire a need for social reform and movements that will empower oppressed and alienated populations? Should we be so quick to cover up the ‚Äútags‚Äù and ‚Äúthrow-ups‚Äù we see, or should we take a moment to look past the ‚Äúugliness‚Äù of the vandalism and study the ugliness of oppression, corruption, political misconduct, and violation of human rights?

For more on this, you can follow the link in our bio to read the longer version of this post.

item.content:encoded:
Due to his godlike social status and a habit of manipulating patents, Thomas A. Edison is often credited with inventing the first motion picture camera.

This is far from reality.

The first functioning motion picture camera was a result of the arduous work of two men that lived on opposite sides of the planet. By the 1870s, the American photographer Eadweard Muybridge and the French scientist Etienne-Jules Marey both had the same, somewhat strange, goal. They wanted to measure the precise movements of horses in motion. Because of the limitations of the human eye, a horse‚Äôs gait was a serious intellectual debate of the time. While Marey wanted to use this knowledge to perfect a scientific method to prove Charles Darwin‚Äôs theory of evolution, Muybridge was commissioned by a railroad tycoon to find out if a horse lifted all four legs off the ground while trotting.
_________

In 1877 Muybridge built a special track with 12 electrically operated cameras that were triggered by a running horse tripping over a series of wires. This led to 12 pictures of a horse running taken in succession. For the first time, the human eye was able to see the exact movements of a horse in stride. Muybridge also succeeded at his task of proving that a horse does lift all four legs off the ground while trotting.
_________

By 1879, Muybridge repeated his experiment, this time with 24 cameras. He also developed a machine used for projecting the images from a motion wheel on a large screen. He traveled across America and Europe showcasing his invention. In France, Muybridge met with the extremely curious Etienne-Jules Marey, who was greatly inspired by the successful experiment.
_________

Marey, however, argued that the 24 separate cameras did not provide the level of consistency needed for proper scientific experiments. Therefore, he decided on creating a single, gun-like, device able to record at least 12 frames per second. In 1882, Marey succeeded. His rifle shaped camera was capable of taking 12 photographs on one plate in one second.
This was the first-ever motion picture camera.

No one will see you the way you see yourself in a mirror.
Sometimes, I stare at myself in the mirror the same way I stare at paintings.

People see my face every day. I see it too, but it‚Äôs not unique, not truly real until I stare at it in the mirror for an uncomfortable period of time. I stare, looking into my eyes, letting minutes pass, moving forward and backward, retreating and advancing, feeling as if I am being watched by someone I don‚Äôt know.
It was frightening seeing myself in the mirror with a blank, emotionless look the other night. That face rarely meets the public‚Äôs eye. It‚Äôs just for me, my little secret. It makes me happy knowing my face has secrets.
Here‚Äôs what I want from you.
Stare at yourself in the mirror. Look at yourself just like you look at this painting.
Observe, create deeper meaning, find the mistakes that prove imperfection is a feature of beauty, take a step away to see the bigger picture, move closer to determine what you want to see in yourself, and decide on your favorite colors.

Who here has heard of Michael Collins?

If you haven‚Äôt, I can‚Äôt blame you. His extraordinary achievements are often overshadowed by those of his colleagues, Neil and Buzz, the first men to ever step on the moon 50 years ago. While these men were cementing the United States‚Äô victory in the worldwide space race, Collins was ensuring that their lunar lander (Eagle) could safely rendezvous with the command module (Columbia) miles above the moon‚Äôs surface.
He spent 21.5 hours orbiting the moon alone in the Columbia. Each orbit, the Columbia would dip around to the far side of the moon, and Collins would be without radio contact for a full 48 minutes. It‚Äôs the loneliest a person could possibly be, one would think. However, Collins repeatedly mandates that loneliness wasn‚Äôt on his mind; he was more concerned for the welfare of his crewmates on the lunar surface below.

Collins passed the time by recording short notes on his tape recorder, rehearsing the 18 different docking maneuvers that he had personally designed. He also preformed maintenance checks and housekeeping chores, all while preparing for rendezvous.

Once the lander had finished its mission and had taken off from the lunar surface, it was Michael Collins‚Äô job to assure that the Columbia and Eager were aligned to the centimeter. Even the smallest mistake would be catastrophic, leaving the astronauts stranded in the Eagle 385,000 kilometers from Earth.

The successful mission would have been a brutal failure without Michael Collins‚Äô bravery, focus, and determination. A true American hero, Collins was instrumental in the most pivotal adventure of the 20th century.

If you want to tile a floor with a single shape of equal sides, how many different options would you have? 50? 100? Infinitely many?

Nope, 3. Only triangles, squares and hexagons. This is a property of the geometry you learn in school, which is constructed from straight lines. But are there other kinds of geometry?

Yes!! And they can be beautiful. One version, known as hyperbolic geometry is my personal favorite.
In the second image you can see the basis for the French mathematician Herni Poincar√©‚Äôs model of hyperbolic geometry, it‚Äôs based on inscribed circles that intersect perpendicular to the outer circle.
In the third image you can see one of these Poincar√© disks colored all pretty.

In the fourth image, you can see a hyperbolic tessellation. As it turns out, there are infinitely many regular tessellations in this geometry vs. the 3 in the first one.

This beauty caught the eye of the visionary artist M.C. Escher. He created images based on advances in mathematics. [the last 5 images are Escher‚Äôs work]

But does this new math have any real use?

Yes, yes it does. While Escher was creating masterpieces, so was Stephen Hawking. Using a hyperbolic geometry, he created a mathematical way of extending the laws of physics beyond the observable universe. This breakthrough also implied an edge to the infinite universe (yes, you read that right) and also laid the groundwork for the Holographic Principle which predicts that our universe is a hologram (holy shit). If there‚Äôs any interest in learning more about these topics, let us know![@matthewzehnbauer]

¬†the faces I'd see again,
¬†only in my dreams.
¬†seeing his home,
¬†with flaking beige paint dressing the exterior,
¬†reminded me of Barr√© breaking through the canvas to reveal what's hidden beneath a painting,
¬†a myriad of emotions, stories, and secrets.
¬†the last time I saw J.D. was what‚Ä¶
¬†twelve, thirteen years ago?
¬†we paused in his doorway,
¬†measuring the effect of time on us.
¬†he was frailer but still had a commanding presence
¬†with his shoulders back,
¬†a tip he got from Sean Connery he told me at that¬†caf√© years ago.
¬†I imagined he noticed the weight I put on,

¬†he lived alone, aloof,

¬†he mimicked their "any day now" attitude with her forced smiles and his uppity demeanor whenever the kid was brought up.

¬†it saddened me seeing him in this state,

¬†at nearly 90,

¬†no,

¬†Every Lost Moment is Life.
¬†the film was 90 minutes, black and white

Peter Mendelsund‚Äôs What We See When We Read feels like witnessing a reflective and contented Marshall McLuhan in old age, casting aside his worries of techno-degenerated human communication and instead peacefully meandering through the halls of his most beloved medium: the printed book.

It‚Äôs good. And it feels good to read.

We don‚Äôt talk about reading enough. It‚Äôs become so associated with antiquity, we forget that not all old things age.

Reading (and writing) are the foundations of formalized symbolism. We may not read books, but we will always read.

Mendelsund brings the experience of reading into focus in a way I haven‚Äôt thought about until now. I‚Äôll be revisiting this one for a while.

I wish I was born at the middle of this century.
¬†the responsibility to lead, to mold
¬†a new age is too burdensome. ¬†the future begins in the fifties.
¬†everything before is old ideas, old methods, old faces.
¬†in 50 AD, Philo of Alexandria died.
¬†he told us that God exists without physical features,
¬†with no emotional capacity, no name.
¬†God only exists in the mind,
¬†transcending time and space
¬†whose home is nowhere and
¬†who never intervenes in our world.
¬†Philo was born before Jesus,
¬†he never wrote of Jesus.
¬†because he lived too soon.
¬†he heard that God embodied Himself within a man who was born into this world,
¬†who inhaled the same air as Philo did,
¬†who spoke a human language,
¬†who had a sensual existence as he did.
¬†a man?
no.
¬†God does not exist in the flesh,
¬†but only as a story,
¬†a triumphant and enduring allegory of the human condition where humans can chose to die for an abstract cause
¬†instead of living just to live, clinging onto material existence because infinite darkness scares us.
¬†heaven is not real,
¬†Adam and Eve is fiction,
¬†the creation of the world in six days is refutable,
¬†since only humans have a sense of time,
¬†we invented the separation of nature into different, categorical orders.
¬†a sunset does not exist,
¬†it is a human separation of light and space
¬†into a wonderful spectacle.
¬†Philo was not interested in wild stories of a poor,
¬†wandering prophet who supposedly healed the sick and rose the dead.
¬†Philo had faith in the greeks, who also believed in deities.
¬†He was an expert in the platonic study of logos.
¬†He believed only humans can maintain divine beauty,
¬†create temples that honor both the living and the dead, because in God's universe,
¬†humans can only aspire, they can never become.
¬†become what? a mystery, an unfinished story. no beginning, no end, constant creation and recreation.
¬†we call the latter History,
¬†we call the former God.
¬†I don't know if Philo wished to be born on the year of his death.
¬†but if he was born in 50 AD,
¬†he could have become Paul or Peter,
¬†the spokesman and rock of early Christianity.
¬†his vision, too prescient.
but prescience
is decided posthumously...

a common connection
___________
he looked bored, maybe anxious.
when we spoke he looked serious,
like a philosopher about to muddy the water.
his eyes darted to the back of the caf√©,
he must have been disturbed by the mysterious man in the corner,
who drank alone,
thought alone,
he met my eyes after we both glanced at the fiery orange haired one who walked in with her low cut dress and plump red lips.
a common link finally,
women. ‚Äúso you‚Äôre twice married. any plans on a third?‚Äù
his words flowed out of a deep sigh,
‚Äúhuhhhh-well... at this point I‚Äôll take my right hand over any woman. It doesn‚Äôt talk back to me, always makes me my food, and will protect me if anyone gets smart with me!‚Äù 76 years old and still a boy.
I must say he‚Äôs a well financed and engineered 76.
No wrinkles, the well toned muscles that his deliberate choice of slim cut clothing accentuates them well and
of course
the smug smile of a man that continues to evade Death‚Äôs calling.
I laugh at his response, but only because I felt sorry for him.
older men need the satisfaction of knowing they can still make young men laugh.
this meeting was too critical, to career catapulting for me to take the moral high ground for a single moment.
despite my credentials which usually raise a brow or two among my peers,
he only accepted the one credential I earned without effort:
youth.
credentials only go so far with a man who recalls a different youth,
whose fight for justice is muted by today‚Äôs injustice,
whose parents are both dead,
an orphan,
he will not bother to make sense of my view of the world he helped create.
i don‚Äôt blame him.
overall, the interview was a failure.
we were at our final bland, watered down sip of cointreau on the rocks.
with it came a moment of rueful introspection, somewhere
between self-pity
and self-exoneration.
we went outside.
inside
we confessed nothing,
we learned nothing.
but outside,
we lit our cigarettes and exhaled,
or more accurately,
we sighed.
the low lying, dark clouds above us trapped the crimson sun,
like a fiery orange hell.
we looked at each other and smiled.
A common connection,
finally.

One never questions the reality of what one sees in front of them. One only conceptualizes it differently.

There are over five hundred properties in the world that are listed in the U.N.'s¬†Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (#UNESCO) database as a World Heritage Site. Yesterday, eight properties were inaugurated into UNESCO. All eight came from one man, one American, Frank Llyod Wright.

The properties include Fallingwater in Pennsylvania, the Guggenheim Museum in New York, the Hollyhock House in Los Angeles, the Jacobs House in Wisconsin, the Robie House in Chicago, Taliesin in Wisconsin, Taliesin West in Arizona and the Unity Temple in Illinois.

These buildings now share the same status as Machu Picchu, the Pyramids of Giza, and the Statue of Liberty. So what makes his buildings worthy of such company?

Two words: organic architecture.

He made buildings in the image of his materials and surroundings, whereas most modern architects use materials in the image of buildings. He believed his materials had themes and central ideas that were all based on what they were made of, and he made them literally a part of their surroundings as naturally as possible. He was the first architect to use concrete the way he did, making whole buildings out of it because of how it can be molded to any shape you want and it will always hold.

throughout the night i glance out of the window to see the man they say healed the sick and rose the dead.
the fat one bellows,
-a messiah who lets himself be crucified,
have you ever heard such a thing!
the people are hysterical, the drinking hastens.
i‚Äôll admit, my mind is thawing and my body is loosening with the wine.
the more i drink,
the more i agree with the fat one.
a messiah who came to save me
couldn‚Äôt even save himself!
funny right?
time is passing, i am laughing, i am dancing, i am living.
but then i remember the hill,
i look once more.
the crowds have dispersed and the crosses are shadowy profiles against the grey sky.
i turn to the party and observe the scene,
accept me! we cry.
we drank tonight,
except me! the messiah cries.
i‚Äôm handled another drink,
cheers to the messiah!
we stumble out to the street
and i see men huddled next to a fire.
i try to listen to their hushed conversation to cure my dizziness,
the fragile looking one with the boyish face says:
only real things are invulnerable to fire,
what can burn is never true,
what burns and needs to be rebuilt
is human.
fire is divine. it burns...
and if i touch it, i am frightened by its intensity!
if i am consumed by it, i become it.
his words make me tense
i am burning up, wine always makes me hot.
i look at the hill once more.
i no longer see the bloodied crosses,
only darkness.
i turn around and the men are gone,
the party is over,
the street is still,
but the fire is still burning. (@joe_delvicario)

What does it mean to be morally responsible?

On August 1st, 1966 Charles Whitman climbed the 27-story observation deck at the University of Texas. He killed 15 people and wounded 33 others.

In what was essentially his suicide note, Whitman described a change in his emotions. He outlined his newfound rage and desire to cause harm, before instructing doctors to perform an autopsy in order to figure out what the hell was going on.

The photo above is a scan of Charles Whitman‚Äôs brain. Shown on that scan is a tumor pressing on his amygdala- a roughly almond-shaped mass
of gray matter found inside each cerebral hemisphere, and involved with the feeling of emotions. This is exactly the place where a tumor would have the effects experienced by Whitman. Assuming the tumor played a role is his actions, was Charles Whitman an evil man? Was he morally responsible for his actions? [ @matthewzehnbauer ]

Men

with money,
who feel old,
because everyone looks young,
whose curiosity with the world

they hide
behind truth,
in front of women,
when tears fall

when tears cease,
a man represses
instead of rebuilds,
when his father dies
he tells himself he's really a man now,
but when his mother dies
he ceases to exist,
when his mother dies
he admits he is a boy
in need of a mother
who will explain the world to him
let him cry,
help him rebuild
all those misspent years
when he thought he was a man
because others told him so,
without mothers and fathers,
men learn what it means to be a man:
to be a son.

The Bearded Woman, also known by its Spanish name, La Mujer Barbuda, is certainly one of the strangest, most foreboding images in the history of art.¬† The painting was commissioned in 1631 by the Duke of Alcal√°, the Viceroy of Naples, who heard rumors of Magdalena‚Äôs physique but never saw her himself.
Here's the portrait of the fifty-two-year-old Magdalena Ventura with her husband and a newborn baby.

At first glance, Magdalena Ventura was far from a typical wife and mother. She sports a beard even longer and more luxurious than that of her husband, who gazes forlornly at the viewer from the murky, shadowy background.

One of the underlying themes of The Bearded Woman is Ribera's attempt to subtly reinforce Magdalena's femininity. This is most strongly suggested by the exposure of her strange, Cyclops-like breast as she nurses a newborn infant.¬†Magdalena was fifty-two years old and her three sons were assuredly no longer breastfeeding. Therefore, this baby is symbolic, serving to emphasize the fact that, despite her luxurious beard, the subject of this portrait is emphatically a woman. (@joe_delvicario)

Pause after you read this story and decide whether the people in the story did anything morally wrong.

A family‚Äôs dog was killed by a car in front of their house. They had heard that dog meat was delicious, so they cut up the dog‚Äôs body, cooked it and ate it. Nobody saw them do this.

This thought experiment comes from Jonathan Haidt‚Äôs book The Righteous Mind. Haidt goes on to give a slightly more challenging story. Again, read this then pause and decide whether the people involved did anything morally wrong.

A man goes to the supermarket once a week and buys a dead chicken. But before cooking the chicken, he has sexual intercourse with it. Then he cooks it and eats it. No one knows he does this.

These questions and their answers help build a foundation for understating morality, the role of disgust, and the power of intuitions.

item.content:encoded:
We live in an era of holidays, where it seems like every day, we are being told to celebrate something completely pointless for the not so subtle purpose of whetting America‚Äôs insatiable appetite for brand awareness and mindless consumerism. National Cookie Day. National Ugly Sweater Day. National Pie Day. You get the point.

However, the origins of Father‚Äôs Day are very genuine, tinged with sadness and can be specifically traced back to a little town in West Virginia called Monongah.

On December 6, 1907, 367 men were working in Fairmont Coal Company mines when, unexpectedly, an explosion occurred which killed an estimated 362 of the miners, with only four escaping and one being rescued by those who came to help. Sadly, the four who escaped later died due to injuries related to the incident. The Monongah Mining Disaster is widely considered ‚Äúthe worst mining disaster in American History‚Äù and devastated the surrounding community, as it estimated that over 1,000 children lost their fathers.

The idea of the town having a day to honor fathers began with Mrs. Grace Golden Clayton, who approached her minister at William‚Äôs Memorial Methodist Episcopal Chruch South with her plan. Although Clayton had not lost her father during the mining explosion, she was deeply affected by his death in 1896, which caused her to feel great sympathy for those who had lost their fathers.

So despite the fact that Father‚Äôs Day would not become an official holiday until 1972 by President Nixon, Monongah is the place where Father‚Äôs Day is most historically associated. (@joe_delvicario)

This banner was photographed at a recent protest against the Chinese Communist Party‚Äôs (CCP) encroachment on Hong Kong‚Äôs democratic process.
The banner reads: ‚ÄúI thought: hope cannot be said to exist, nor can it be said not to exist. It is just like roads across the earth. For actually the earth had no roads to begin with, but when many men pass one way, a road is made.‚Äù __________

These words come from Lu Xun‚Äôs short story, ‚ÄúMy Old Home.‚Äù Xun‚Äôs influence on the Chinese people has remained remarkably resilient since his writings reached the public in the early twentieth century.
Xun depicted a laggard China at the turn of the twentieth century. Poverty, medicinal and technological backwardness, and the panopticon of oppression were present in this China. With democracy and pluralism muted for millions of Chinese citizens, Western nations amassed conspicuous amounts of wealth with the nod from the Qing Dynasty who were financially indebted to European powers.
_________

Today, the people of Hong Kong march with Xun by their sides in their fight to protect democracy and pluralism. Since 1997, the year Hong Kong shed its British skin and became an independent territory, the CCP has made multiple attempts to incorporate Hong Kong under their jurisdiction.
_________

Please keep an eye on the protests currently being held in Hong Kong. The CCP has been relentless in their quest for Hong Kong. We may witness a final vestige of democracy collapse in China if Hong Kong fails to remain politically independent.

Au Lapin Agile.
Picasso painted ‚ÄúThe Agile Rabbit‚Äù in 1905, the year Einstein‚Äôs theory of relativity first appeared and two years before Picasso painted Les Demoiselles d‚ÄôAvignon.
_____

He is seated nearest to us, holding his breath for eternity in the Lapin Agile, a popular cabaret in the 18th Arrondissement of Paris. Was Picasso referring to the profiled Germaine Pichot seated beside him as the agile rabbit? Picasso, like a hunter of wild game, searched for the female spoor with pen and brush as his weapons of choice. He has found her, but Germaine could not look any more disinterested. Her mind is adrift in a far-flung, cavernous space while her body remains trapped in the poky cabaret with misfits and wannabes. Picasso is dressed as a harlequin, a colloquial term for a theater jester who wore diamond-patterned costumes. However, a harlequin is also a small duck known for its ability to navigate fast-moving streams. Stay here with me.
_____

Picasso, the harlequin, navigates the fast-moving streets of Paris at the turn of the twentieth century. The twentieth century... where no political movement would be as glorious as the movement of the line across paper. The twentieth century began in the caf√©s and bars, where misfits and wannabes like Picasso, Chagall, Hemingway and Einstein determined they would dedicate their lives to the pursuit of a new Star of Bethlehem for the modern world.
_____

We are still searching for that star.
j.d.

item.description:

Adult cicadas only live for a couple of weeks, but the nymph ...
item.content:encoded:
What do cicadas have to do with math?

Adult cicadas only live for a couple of weeks, but the nymph stage lasts for 13 years in some varieties, and 17 years in others.

The adults come out of the ground at almost the exact same moment, having spent either 13 or 17 years nestled underground. The result is a spectacular eruption of loud little insects.

A remarkable fact, which comes from Richard Dawkins‚Äô ‚ÄòThe Blind Watchmaker‚Äô, is that there isn‚Äôt just one 13-year species and one 17-year species, rather there are THREE species, and each one of those three has both a 17-year and a 13-year variety, or race.
This division into two races of 13 and 17-year cycles has been arrived at independently at least THREE times.

The plot thickens once you discover that there are no varieties with 14, 15 and 16-year cycles. Why? Well, no one knows for sure, but a hypothesis that I find beautiful, suggests that prime numbers are playing a role here.

A prime number, depending which mathematician you ask, is a number which is only divisible by itself and 1. The idea here is that any species that regularly erupts in plagues gains the benefit of going back and forth between ‚Äòswamping‚Äô and starving it‚Äôs predators.

If these plagues are timed carefully to occur a prime number of years apart, it makes it much more difficult for the predators to synchronize their own life cycles. If the cicadas erupted every 14 years, for example, they could be exploited by a species with a 7-year life cycle.

We don‚Äôt know what‚Äôs special about 13 and 17 years, but evolutionarily speaking, something is important, since three separate species have converged on them independently. [m.z.]

Today marks 30 years since the #TiananmenSquare Massacre. There are a variety of things that are extraordinary about this anniversary.
__________

First of all, as we are talking about it 30 years on, the government is still trying to repress discussion of it. Even though the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) is, in many ways, in a position of strength akin to the Mao years, at this moment you can‚Äôt help but see a deep insecurity by the CCP in its lack of confidence in making its own story stick. It has a story that it sometimes tells, about it being necessary to use force to create the stability that China needed to develop. But it obviously isn‚Äôt confident enough of that story to allow broad discussion of what took place many Junes ago. The more I think about it, the reason why I think it has so much trouble dealing with it is that a core part of the story that the CCP tells its people about why it deserves to rule has to do with the People‚Äôs Liberation Army (PLA). The PLA was the force that helped liberate the Chinese people from mistreatment by disloyal rulers who sold China to foreign partners. But what we saw 30 years ago was the People‚Äôs Liberation Army behaving very much like an army of occupation. This is an obstacle that the West should highlight more.
_________

Another interesting point to be made is Tiananmen‚Äôs aura of Stalinism. A trademark of Stalin‚Äôs version of communism was the state‚Äôs monopoly on violence against its own people. In 1989, Eastern Europe‚Äôs Iron Curtain fell and was shed to pieces by the millions who lived in the shadows of the burgeoning democratic world for far too long. In contrast to Eastern Europe, the 1989 protests in China did not lead to the overthrow of the Communist Party. Therefore, China is the final vestige of one of history‚Äôs most dramatic civilizational projects: Stalinist communism. (j.d.)

item.description: Each night, as winter turns to spring, millions and millions of birds fly overhead, migrating toward...
item.content:encoded:
Each night, as winter turns to spring, millions and millions of birds fly overhead, migrating towards the beckoning wide open spaces of the North. They follow the explosive ‚Äúleaf out‚Äù of the deciduous forests and the insect protein it brings, as well as the opportunity to stake out a territory, find a mate, and make a name for themselves. If you‚Äôre lucky, an opposing wind might force a momentary pause, affording a few days to discover exotic travelers who hail from deep within a balmy rainforest or iridescent South American grassland, now resting in your backyard.

It used to be the best way to track these migrants would be to turn a pair of binoculars towards the moon in hopes of identifying a silhouette. We‚Äôve come a long way since then. The above animated map comes from eBird- a citizen science platform that allows naturalists world-wide to contribute their observations to conservation and research. I highly encourage you to check it out.

During a transformative trip through Costa Rica with a biology class, I remember tracing a Barn Swallow carve the air acrobatically to catch invisible insects over an expansive wetland. My professor informed me that they are North American migrants and can be seen back in New York too. A wave of admiration and closeness fell over me as I realized the tiny Swallow would journey with me all the way back home.
Since that trip, recognizing the vibrant plumage of a Neptropical migrant arises within me a profound sense of connection and deeper identity. To have experiences with nature is to be a part of it. I hope this post inspires you to look closer, stay longer, and discover your own secret community. [s.g.] #eBird #cornelllabofornithology

She loses the melodramatic lines and begins to enchant this California raisin of a man with her waltzing eyes and her soft words. item.content:encoded:
Vasily Kandinsky‚Äôs ‚ÄúYellow-Red-Blue‚Äù (1925) is a textbook example of the color triad: primary, secondary, and tertiary.

We can infer from the title of this work that Kandinsky wants us to see how primary colors‚Äî red, yellow, & blue‚Äî are accentuated when blended into one portrait with the secondary colors of orange, green, and violet.
If you look closely, you can then see the tertiary colors of red-orange, yellow-orange, yellow-green, blue-green, blue-violet, and red-violet.

The color triad is ubiquitous, even primordial, in art.
Take Mary Cassatt‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Boating Party‚Äù (1893-94). Blue and yellow dominate this scene, with touches of red seen on the mother and daughter. Now, you see the green as well, right? Cassatt used green to balance blue and yellow, just as it does on the color wheel where it rests between the two (third image). Try and break down the color triad of the next beautiful sunset you catch yourself marveling at.
I hope we can begin to look at the world just as we look at these paintings. (@joe_delvicario)
