item.description: Trees along a highway appear to be moving from the perspective a car passing by, but stationary to a...
item.content:encoded:
Trees along a highway appear to be moving from the perspective a car passing by, but stationary to a hitch-hiker sitting on a guardrail. Similarly, the dashboard of the car appears stationary from the perspective of the passengers, but appears to be moving from the point of view of the hitch-hiker. This claim is so basic and intuitive that we hardly take note of it.

#AlbertEinstein ‚Äòs Theory of Special Relativity proclaims that the differences between two observers are more subtle than one might expect.

#SpecialRelativity states that observers in relative motion will have different perceptions of distance and time.
This means that identical wristwatches worn by two individuals in relative motion will tick at different rates and hence will not agree on the amount of time that elapses between chosen events. Special Relativity demonstrates that this statement does not slander the accuracy of the wristwatches involved; rather it is a true statement about time itself.

Similarly, observers in relative motion carrying identical tape measures will not agree on the lengths of distances measured. Again, this is not due to inaccuracies in the measuring devices or to errors in how they used, but is a property about distance itself.

For more on this topic, check out ‚ÄòThe Elegant Universe‚Äô by theoretical physicist, Brian Greene.
[m.z.]

item.description: [j.d.] When the first e-reader appeared, printed books were declared dead. It hasn't happened ‚Äì and ...
item.content:encoded:
[j.d.]
When the first e-reader appeared, printed books were declared dead. It hasn't happened ‚Äì and there are no signs that it will. The brittle plastic of an e-reader, however colorful the cove, doesn't have the physical presence of a printed volume. Nor can a click on the ‚Äòbuy now‚Äô button on the Kindle Store replicate a lunch hour spent sauntering a bookshop and rummaging through the contents of an aisle piled high with out-of-print treasures.
_____

But did you know printed books were declared ‚Äùdead‚Äù much earlier than the appearance of the e-reader?
_____
In 1894, in an essay entitled ‚ÄùThe End of Books,‚Äù French writer Octave Uzanne wrote: ‚ÄùReading, as we practice it today, soon brings on great weariness; for not only does it require of the brain a sustained attention which consumes a large proportion of the cerebral phosphates, but it also forces our bodies into various fatiguing attitudes.‚Äù Books are desirable objects. They are made to be read and to be displayed. They ask to be touched and turned, with each volume exuding a distinct odor that sends us back to the time the pages were last opened.
I‚Äôm sure Uzanne would agree with me, considering he authored multiple books over his illustrious career. But books were not the focus of his 1894 essay evidently. It was the act of reading. Uzanne was a marvelous observer of his own time. He figured that with the advancements in visual and phonographic technology, reading could transform into a leisure activity which required no use of the physical book in hand. With the competitiveness of innovation and changing urban landscapes, Uzanne made the prescient prediction that modern society will not have the time, not the will power, to sit still and focus their mind on ink amidst new technologies.
_____
‚ÄúEither the books must go, or they must swallow us up. [...] Our social condition forces us to hear many stupid things every day. A few more or less do not amount to very great suffering in the end; but what happiness not to be obliged to read them, and to be able at last to close our eyes upon the annihilation of printed things!‚Äù

item.content:encoded:
Take a moment to read this excerpt from Brook Adams‚Äô 1903 work, The New Empire. As I read this page this morning, I found this highlighted paragraph to be one of the most important excerpts I have found in quite some time.
_____
If you remove the United States and place China here, what do we see? We the Belt and Road Initiative. The impact of the Panama Canal then is analogous to the effects of the 2008 Financial Crisis. The Crisis stymied the American development model in Asia and placed China at the center of Asia‚Äôs development ever since. In a very real sense, what we saw in 2008 was the shifting allegiance of billions of people from Washington to Beijing in a matter of weeks. When Adams stated the United States was an ‚Äúimperial economy,‚Äù he would have found it unfathomable to picture a future where the U.S. competed with China for global power. Remember, in 1903, China had yet to abolish the civil service test, concubinage, and was still ruled by the Qing Dynasty. Furthermore, European and American delegations carved up much of China‚Äôs fertile eastern coast and its cities after the Boxer Rebellion of 1900.
______
‚ÄúThe West Indies drift towards us, the Republic of Mexico hardly longer has an independent life, and the city of Mexico is an American town.‚Äù Could we not revise this to fit our contemporary mold? ‚ÄúEurope drifts towards us, Central Asia hardly longer has an independent life, and the city of Urumqi is a Chinese town.‚Äù

item.title: Norman Rockwell was criticized by those in the art world as being not an artist but an illustrator. ...
item.description: Norman Rockwell was criticized by those in the art world as being not an artist but an illustrator. ...
item.content:encoded:
Norman Rockwell was criticized by those in the art world as being not an artist but an illustrator. His optimistic and appealing style was exoteric and therefore at odds with the demands of esoteric academic evaluations. I recently discovered the word exoteric: "intended for or likely to be understood by the general public‚Äù in contrast to esoteric: ‚Äúintended for or likely to be understood by only a small number of people with a specialized knowledge or interest.‚Äù Rockwell illustrated covers for the US‚Äôs most popular magazine, the Saturday Evening Post, from 1916 to 1963, boosting sales every time. Magazine covers require intuitive content, which is likely the reason for the art world‚Äôs dismissal of him. Art can be intuitive, but it should also allow the viewer to look further and deeper, to reflect on one‚Äôs own connotation within the denotation.

Although oriented for the masses as he was, does Rockwell truly provide nothing further for the viewer to consider? I reject this for one simple reason: Rockwell is funny!
His Triple Self-Portrait is all tongue in cheek. Tasked with painting himself, he decides to paint himself painting himself. His tilted body language, the precarious glass of Coca Cola, and the metal pail smoking with pipe ash all draw a smile. Rockwell‚Äôs use of humor and character to tell a story allows the masses to participate in introspective consideration just as more conceptually layered art does.
Cast in this light, it seems the art world‚Äôs dismissal of Rockwell comes from a sense of superiority. With all of their specialized (read: esoteric) knowledge, he provides nothing for them to do. Yes, Rockwell is likely to be seen in a nursing home or dentist‚Äôs office more than in a museum, but maybe that‚Äôs the point.

Ironically, Andy Warhol‚Äôs pop art (or modern art) revolution would begin a decade or so later, taking consumer icons and repurposing them into works which were esoteric and exoteric at the same time. Rockwell may predate Warhol‚Äôs partnering art for the masses with intellectualized art, but by adding the human universal of story to his vignettes, he found a new partnership: art for the masses and art for the soul. @sagegibbons

item.description: You would like to apologize to your wife for the ugliness you have spread across the flowers she has...
item.content:encoded:
You would like to apologize to your wife
for the ugliness you have spread across
the flowers she has personally tended.

You have put blood on the blossoms and it won't
wash off. If beauty is a human valuation, then
is the ugliness of murder equally subjective?
This corpse between the flowers and your eyes,
perhaps it's wrong to think it wrong, just
as it is foolish to think the flowers
beautiful.

Some days all the answers are bad ones.
Some days there is only the word Stop
and you try to make a wall of it and repeatedly
beat your head against it. But of course
nothing stops and it is foolish to think so.
There is only this constant ongoingness
until your own private light blinks out:
the cruel variety, the savage bouquet,
the world's victims interspersed with flowers.

___________

Marc Chagall

A few nights ago, a young and ambitious female reporter was murdered in a domestic terrorist attack. While this headline is commonplace in many parts of the world, it is quite saddening to learn that its source comes from Northern Ireland.
Today, the Irish Republican Army (IRA) claimed responsibility for the murdering of Lyra McKee. The IRA is back, but only in the pages of the international press. If you are a resident in Belfast, the news of the McKee‚Äôs death won't come as a surprise.
According to the Belfast-based organization Detail Data, the IRA was responsible for 22 killings, more than 1,000 shootings and bombings, 787 paramilitary-style attacks and nearly 4,000 reports of people forced to flee their homes between 2006 and 2015.
The Troubles is back. But then again, did it ever end?

item.title: Twenty-five years ago today, Richard Nixon passed away at the age of 81. In the words of Hunter S. ...
item.description: Twenty-five years ago today, Richard Nixon passed away at the age of 81. In the words of Hunter S. ...
item.content:encoded:
Twenty-five years ago today, Richard Nixon passed away at the age of 81.
In the words of Hunter S. Thompson from his 1994 eulogy to the late president: ‚ÄùHe was scum.

Let there be no mistake in the history books about that. Richard Nixon was an evil man -- evil in a way that only those who believe in the physical reality of the Devil can understand it. He was utterly without ethics or morals or any bedrock sense of decency. Nobody trusted him -- except maybe the Stalinist Chinese, and honest historians will remember him mainly as a rat who kept scrambling to get back on the ship.

He was a cheap crook and a merciless war criminal who bombed more people to death in Laos and Cambodia than the U.S. Army lost in all of World War II, and he denied it to the day of his death. When students at Kent State University, in Ohio, protested the bombing, he connived to have them attacked and slain by troops from the National Guard.

Some people will say that words like scum and rotten are wrong for Objective Journalism -- which is true, but they miss the point. It was the built-in blind spots of the Objective rules and dogma that allowed Nixon to slither into the White House in the first place. He looked so good on paper that you could almost vote for him sight unseen. He seemed so all-American, so much like Horatio Alger, that he was able to slip through the cracks of Objective Journalism. You had to get Subjective to see Nixon clearly, and the shock of recognition was often painful.‚Äù

item.content:encoded:
Earth Day is a day of confession. We sinners look to the earth, our priest, for penance. The absolution we wish will not come in the form of prayer or meditation. It will go only by action.
There are plenty of ways to mitigate the damage humans inflict on nature. Some damage is reversible. Most is not. The one thing we can reverse is our relationship to nature.
Here in Binghamton, nature is suppressed by human faculties. The carcass of the industrial era rots alongside budding flowers and chirping birds. Car exhaustion lingers longer than the sound of air shuffling the leaves. The mechanized sounds of the old factories survive in the streets.
But remember that nature is not a sleeping giant. Just as the priest stands alone in dying churches amidst rising cities, nature is always with us to remind us we have an eternal home, Earth.

item.content:encoded:
One of the latest plans for the restoration of Notre Dame. Thoughts?
____________

Norman Foster, British architect and head of the international design firm Foster + Partners, is quoted in the London Times: "submissions should¬†embrace the boldness of the original builders, who pushed the limits of the technology of the day with their flying buttresses." Lord Foster was responsible for the 1999 reconstruction of the Reichstag in Berlin. The glass dome that now rests atop the Reichstag replaced the original stone dome which was destroyed during the Second World War. Lord Foster's proposed glass spire aspires to become a work of art that can wed our contemporary zeitgeist to the eternity of spirituality.

Foster's plan has the approval of other notable architects such as Ian Ritchie, creator of the Spire of Dublin, and Ptolemy Dean, the incumbent Surveyor of the Fabric of Westminster Abbey.

I want to emphasize an important distinction here. What we are witnessing is the difference between restoration and recreation. All art is essentially the result of reflecting on something and then representing it. Lord Foster and his ilk have reflected on the fire and concluded that the roof of Notre Dame could be "reconstructed" to represent modern times architecturally and, more important, symbolically. The reconstruction process also aims to recreate. The contrarians who oppose the glass spire and roof wish to ‚Äùrestore‚Äù them to their original states, but with safer features included to ensure a fire of similar magnitude doesn‚Äôt occur again. By restoring the roof and spire to its original states, the contrarians believe the Notre Dame‚Äôs original corporeal features will continue to illuminate the cathedral without the need of sunlight.

item.content:encoded:
Are we back in the 15th century? This seems like a silly question to ask you, my unknown audience. But as I reflect on today‚Äôs events in Paris and the state of the world, I see much continuity with our past.
A few weeks ago, China secured a multi-billion dollar deal with the Italian government as part of China‚Äôs Belt & Road Initiative. Where did this deal take place? Venice, the city Marco Polo departed from and returned to after his travels along the ancient Silk Road that led to Beijing. China‚Äôs Belt & Road has united Asia with parts of Europe and Africa, recreating the ancient Silk Road and fulfilling the expeditionary vision of Zhang He‚Äôs voyages during the 15th century. Is the Belt & Road Initiative not the new Dutch East India Company in reverse? China has broken history, flattening time as if we were living in Zurvan‚Äôs universe.
The populism in Europe reminds me of the religious zealotry of the Europeans against the Ottomans during the 15th century. It was not uncommon for disenfranchised Westerners to escape Europe and find refuge in Ottoman lands in Northern Africa and the Levant during the 15th century as well. Do we need see the same brain drains and diasporas from these lands to the West now?

The Catholic Church has always been the enemy of current fashions. The Church sets itself against the fashions of this world which will soon pass away. As the many fashions reign and eventually pass (e.g., governments, ideologies, etc.), the Church stands alone, fearless and poised to remind future generations of our story so that we are not forgotten in vain. The Catholic Church has changed in many ways since the 15th century. However, what will not change is the beauty of the monumental statues, the cavernous cathedrals and the timelessness of faith which all show us how much we have changed.
And fallen.

In 2004, the South Korean electronics maker, LG, unveiled what I consider the most innovative cell phone before the iPhone hit markets in 2007.
The LG F7100, known as the Qiblah phone,¬†incorporated built-in longitude and latitude orientation that, when used in comparison to the magnetic north, indicated the direction of Qiblah (the sacred shrine of the Ka'bah in Mecca). The phone's digital compass was also supplemented by a call to prayer alarm which helped the user remember to adhere to the Salat, the five obligatory daily prayers in Islam.
The former Executive Vice President of LG, Kenn Suh, stated:¬†"No matter where the faithful are at the call to prayer, they will be able to easily identify the direction of Mecca with this phone. The Qiblah phone is the product of our on-going effort to meet local and cultural demands. We had conducted market research on the culture and needs of the customers in the Middle East. LG Electronics plans to continually develop and unveil specialized products tailored to the needs of the local market." In 2005, the Netherlands became the first European country to sell a similar phone, the IIkone i800, in its domestic markets.

Americans today harbor no strong or consistent collective memory of the First World War. Ask why we fought or what we accomplished, and "democracy" and ‚Äùfreedom‚Äù are the most likely (dare I say vague) responses. The circulation of confusing or lofty rationales for intervention began as soon as President Woodrow Wilson secured a war declaration from Congress in April 1917.
__________
America is alone in its quixotic imagination of the First World War. We see this exemplified in the contrast between American and European perceptions of world order and history. Ever since the First World War, Europe has felt an underlying pessimism, a sense of danger and disorder that the United States hasn‚Äôt shared. Americans have continued to believe that progress is built into history. Most Europeans, other than Marxists, dropped this notion once the Great War began.
__________
Europeans still call it the ‚ÄùGreat War‚Äù‚Äînot only because it was catastrophic and momentous, but also because it changed the nature of war itself. Civilian life became a new front line. Europe‚Äôs first genocide seen with the Armenians set the tone for the rest of the century. Empires collapsed and fragile nations remained. The epoch of chemical warfare began (some scholars have determined that in 1918, one out of four shells dropped on the Western Front was poisonous). There's still more to mention, but this space will never truly encapsulate what made the Great War a watershed moment in history.

item.title: Today is Flannery O‚ÄôConnor‚Äôs birthday. I‚Äôve been thinking a lot about what it means to be a writer....
item.description: Today is Flannery O‚ÄôConnor‚Äôs birthday. I‚Äôve been thinking a lot about what it means to be a writer....
item.content:encoded:
Today is Flannery O‚ÄôConnor‚Äôs birthday.
I‚Äôve been thinking a lot about what it means to be a writer. Andr√© Malraux, as usual, comes to mind since he likened the writer to the artist, one who directs their life towards asking questions instead of searching for answers. However, I find Flannery O‚ÄôConnor‚Äôs idea of the writer to be of equal merit.
O‚ÄôConnor advises the writer to be humble before the concrete world. She wrote that, ‚Äúwhat the fiction writer will discover, if he discovers anything at all is that he himself cannot move or mold reality in the interests of abstract truth. The writer learns, perhaps more quickly than the reader, to be humble in the face of what-is. What-is is all he has to do with; the concrete is his medium; and he will realize eventually that fiction can transcend its limitations only by staying within them.‚Äù Like Malraux, O'Connor defines a writer by his or her actions in the concrete world of what-is. The writer questions the world by acting on the page.
______
During a recent conversation with @sagegibbons, we discussed the effectiveness of Michel Houellebecq‚Äôs prose. We agreed that Michel blends fiction with reality unlike the herd of contemporary fictionists since he is not a world-builder like Tolkien or Rowling but instead is a world-deconstructionist. A reader of Submission will agree that Houellebecq does not allude to reality but throws it in your face with the wit of Twain and the precision of a sociologist. But by staying within the bounds of fiction, Houellebecq is allowed to have his ideas transcend the work without being ground to a priori experience. At once, his work is both a priori and a posteriori, a description and prescription of the world.
The beauty of fiction‚Äôs boundaries is that once you enter them, your words can transcend the page and even death.
My definition of the writer is still in the works, but I am grateful to those who have preceded me and whose eternal slumber bears no effect on their ability to remain by my side on my journey of questions.

item.description: In October of 1879, a man named Theo went to visit his brother in Borinage, a Belgian coal-mining di...
item.content:encoded:
In October of 1879, a man named Theo went to visit his brother in Borinage, a Belgian coal-mining district. His brother moved to this remote anthracite abode to continue a Calvinist mission work his father began in the region years prior.

After almost a year in the dark and poverty-stricken landscape of the Borinage, he was losing any clarity he had about the direction his life was heading towards. Before Borinage, he was a teacher, an art dealer, and a bookseller.¬† He brought himself to the furthest limits of his Christian understanding of purpose at Borinage. As he tried to help the destitute community, giving them all of his money and clothes, moving out of the comfortable home he was living in and into a run-down abandoned miner‚Äôs hut, trying to live like them and care for them as Jesus would have, he had come to nothing. No one was saved.

Dismayed by Theo's vindictiveness towards his mission and his own inability to experience anything beyond corporeal existence, he embarked on an artistic pilgrimage to Courrieres to visit the French painter, Jules Breton.

His journey was a way of breaking free from the darkness of the mines and the religious life that held him in Borinage. He was reaching unconsciously for something concrete to hold onto‚Äîconfirmation, perhaps, of the dawning of his call to art.

When he finally got to Courrieres, he could not get himself to enter Breton's home: "for I lacked the courage to enter and introduce myself." Reflecting on his journey to Theo, he wrote: "Well, even in that deep misery I felt my energy revive, and I said to myself, in spite of everything I shall rise again: I will take up my pencil, which I have forsaken in my great discouragement, and I will go on with my drawing. From that moment everything has seemed transformed for me, and now I have started, and my pencil has become somewhat docile, becoming more so every day.‚Äù He never would return to the Borinage. Only through memory and on canvas.
This was the birth of Vincent van Gogh.
____________
Vincent van Gogh, ‚ÄùCoalmine in the Borinage‚Äù (1880)
Jules Breton, ‚ÄùThe Song of the Lark‚Äù (1884)

Chairman Mao: Juxtaposition between Err√≥ and The People‚Äôs Republic of China
__________
In January 1972, France‚Äôs Minister of Culture and grand luminary, Andr√© Malraux, dined with President Nixon at the White House. The topic of the evening was China, or rather, Mao Zedong. The Sino-American relationship at this point in history was at its nadir, with zero active diplomatic channels operating between the two powers. However, the capstone of the Nixon administration‚Äôs policy of d√©tente was the liberalization of Sino-American relations. To achieve this grand plan, Nixon turned to America‚Äôs most erudite military and academic advisors to develop help develop a successful agenda for the planned February visit between him and Chairman Mao Zedong. After multiple sessions between Nixon and his advisors, Henry Kissinger and Nixon realized that a gap in their effort existed, namely, an esoteric diplomat.
__________
China, during the middle of the twentieth century, shed its traditional neo-Confucian skin and grew its contemporary epidermis of communist, ‚Äúhard‚Äù humanism thanks to Mao Zedong. The character, the modus operandi, of the Chinese people and her social-political trajectory laid in the hands of Mao Zedong. Mao‚Äôs tenure as Chairman of the Communist Party was a classic epic performed in a Weberian theater. One man who understood the gravity of Nixon‚Äôs planned meeting with Mao Zedong was Malraux. Malraux had met with Mao on multiple occasions when the leader was both a radical leader in the communist intelligentsia and as Chairman. He knew Mao on a personal level; thus, his insight was esoteric but sacred in the world of rising cities and dying gods.
__________
Andr√© Malraux told Nixon on the eve of his trip: ‚ÄúYou are about to attempt one of the most important things of our century. I think of the sixteenth-century explorers, who set out for a specific objective but often arrived at a totally different discovery. You have the destiny of the world in your hands.‚Äù

item.title: Nineteen years ago, the provocative aesthetic artist Marco Evaristti showcased an exhibit called ‚ÄúHe...
item.description: Nineteen years ago, the provocative aesthetic artist Marco Evaristti showcased an exhibit called ‚ÄúHe...
item.content:encoded:
Nineteen years ago, the provocative aesthetic artist Marco Evaristti showcased an exhibit called ‚ÄúHelena.‚Äù With the intent on challenging the visitors to play Death, he filled ten blenders with a goldfish and allowed them to turn on the blender or grant the fish a pardon. Most of the visitors refused to partake in such an act, but this did not stop a few visitors from pressing the button.

The moralists, voyeurs, and sadists present at the exhibit represent Western society. We in the West are in a nascent state. Yet, we peripatetically maneuver our lives anyway, hoping something will stick and someone will notice. I can‚Äôt decide whether or not the moralist and the voyeur differ, since both become sclerotic by pleasure when faced with taking action. What is certain though is the latent sadism that lurks within us. I know Freud stated that human sadomasochism and barbarism remains in the unconscious thanks to Western civilization‚Äôs ability to thwart the attenuation of social decorum. But who are we kidding? Civilization is an archaic device whose utterance calls foregone faces and ages to mind, not the present age defined by schadenfreude and decadence.

Civilization is defined by the art it produces. This is why Andr√© Malraux once said: ‚ÄúWe do¬†not mind a Rembrandt looking modern, but we resent a modern painting looking like a Rembrandt.‚Äù Malraux‚Äôs point is that by painting to describe the past, instead of painting to explore the present, the painter is imposing a false image to the viewer.

Evaristti‚Äôs work is ultimately an exploration of the present state of civilization: a people filled with ideas and colors, but without a canvas to explore. This is a credible and compelling work of contemporary art.

Yesterday was the 10th anniversary of Heath Ledger‚Äôs posthumous Oscar win for Best Supporting Actor.
___________

When ‚ÄúThe Dark Knight‚Äù arrived in theaters 10 years ago, the ‚Äúcomic-book movie‚Äù centering on superheroes had certainly experienced creative peaks, like the ‚ÄúSuperman‚Äù movies beginning in the ‚Äô70s, Tim Burton‚Äôs 1989 ‚ÄúBatman,‚Äù Bryan Singer‚Äôs first ‚ÄúX-Men‚Äù in 2000, and the launch of Sam the ‚ÄúSpider-Man‚Äù franchise. But in 2008, even after Jon Favreau‚Äôs ‚ÄúIron Man‚Äù birthed the beginning of the Marvel Cinematic Universe that same summer, superhero cinema was not accorded much artistic pedigree. However, this dark Batman sequel scored critically, garnering eight Oscar nominations and winning two, including Heath Ledger‚Äôs hauntingly iconic performance as the Joker.
___________

The Joker was expressive with his eyes, and his voice had undulations of irony and mockery that added a ring of psychopathology to his character. His capricious nature was exemplified by his constant licking of the lips, but a deeper reading could be that his parapraxic ‚Äúslip of the tongues‚Äù was Nolan‚Äôs clever attempt to tap into audience‚Äôs unconscious.
___________

Without Ledger‚Äôs performance, I doubt we would lionize ‚ÄúThe Dark Knight‚Äù as we now do.

This morning, India‚Äôs Minister of Transportation Nitin Gadkari announced that the Modi administration will restrict the flow of its share of water to Pakistan from rivers under the Indus Water Treaty.
This move comes as an immediate response to the fallout of the deadly terrorist attack that killed 40 paramilitary personnel in south Kashmir last week. Following the attack, the government revoked the Most Favoured Nation (MFN) status given to Pakistan and also imposed a 200% customs duty on all imported goods.
Under the Indus Water Treaty, which was signed in 1960, the western rivers- the Indus, Jhelum, and Chenab- was given to Pakistan and those of the eastern rivers- the Ravi, Beas, and Sutlej- to India. Most of Pakistan‚Äôs water comes from these three rivers. The Modi administration insists that the stopping of its share of western water from going to Pakistan is in no way a violation of the landmark 1960 treaty.
Have the Water Wars begun?

Today is the 40th anniversary of the Iranian Revolution.
Once Ayatollah Khomeini‚Äôs feet landed on the tarmac after spending the past fifteen years of exile in France, he ousted the ruling Pahlavi family and established the surviving constitutional theocracy of today. The Pahlavi family had been seen as a pillar of regional stability and a bulwark of US influence against the Soviet Union in Central Asia. But after centuries of Qajar and Pahlavi modernization efforts, Iran was ripe for an insurrection against the Pahlavi government which was the totem of Western influence.
The Revolution was one of the most important events of not only the twentieth century but of world history. For two millennia, Persia was ruled by Shahs whose legitimacy was rooted in brute usurpation of power. But with Khomeini‚Äôs declaration of an Islamic Republic protected by the auspices of the Shia faith, he closed a chapter in Persian history and wrote a new one. Iran now stands as the most dominant theocracy in the world.

January 17, 1945
You‚Äôre sitting in your plump leather chair, reflecting on the last ten years. The 1934 election victory over Patterson makes you chuckle. You look up to see your junior staff politely waiting for you to invite them into your office. Looking at them, you become overwhelmed with emotions. They are now your former staff. In three days, you will be in the White House, serving as Vice President in the Roosevelt administration. One staffer jocularly remarks to you, ‚ÄúNow he can‚Äôt ignore you!‚Äù You remember the hard Depression years and the thousands of Missourians who begged you to bring more federal aid. A slight jolt makes you tremor. It‚Äôs the same jolt you had all those times President Roosevelt ignored your calls. All those begging Missourians, left begging.
____
April 12, 1945
You‚Äôre alone in a room without any windows, only paintings. Outside the door, you hear people crying, quiet murmurs, and no joy. President Roosevelt passed away earlier in the day. You walk outside. Everything stops. The President of the United States has emerged.
____
August 6, 1945
A mushroom cloud rises over Hiroshima. You sit in your plump leather chair, thinking about all those begging Japanese. It‚Äôs silent in the Oval Office, but the world is on fire. Because of you.
____
It has only been 28 weeks.

Rene Magritte was not a painter of faces.
When you flip through these paintings, you will notice that his subjects‚Äô faces are either covered or turned away from our view. When asked why he chose to refrain from allowing the viewer to see ‚Äúthe face‚Äù in his works, he responded: ‚ÄúEverything we see hides another thing, we always want to see what is hidden by what we see. There is an interest in that which is hidden and which the visible does not show us. This interest can take the form of a quite intense feeling, a sort of conflict, one might say, between the visible that is hidden and the visible that is present.‚Äù Magritte‚Äôs cogent answer is a rare example of an artist‚Äôs intentionality. One of Picasso‚Äôs trademark characteristics was his cryptic, pithy remarks to those who asked him what his art meant. This reply allows us to look deeper into his avant-style, Sh√©h√©razade.
The style, named after the female protagonist in ‚ÄúOne Thousand and One Nights,‚Äù is said to have been influenced by Edgar Allen Poe‚Äôs short story, ‚ÄúThe Thousand-and-Second Tale of Scheherazade.‚Äù Poe‚Äôs story begins with the quotable phrase: ‚ÄúTruth is stranger than fiction.‚Äù What Magritte gathered from Poe‚Äôs work is that the truth of seeing a face reveals minimal insight into what lies beneath the skin. Fiction grants us the opportunity to imagine new possibilities which truth‚Äôs finitude fails to offer. When we look at Magritte‚Äôs art, we are actively involved in the search for what is ‚Äúnot‚Äù there, just as the king in ‚ÄúOne Thousand and One Nights‚Äù fell in love with Scheherazade since she represented what was not present in his life: the infinite beauty of fiction.

item.description: Casablanca, which was a small town when the French made it the commercial capital of their protector...
item.content:encoded:
Casablanca, which was a small town when the French made it the commercial capital of their protectorate in 1912, is clearly not ancient. It is not entirely Moroccan in body and soul either. It is a whitewashed city of of sidewalk cafes and fine restaurants with bazaars where you can bargain for carpets and hand-painted plates or just lose yourself among sacks of spices and knock-off Hermes products. However, on this day in 1943, Casablanca was the site of a momentous, ten-day conference which altered the course of the Second World War. _

The sun beat fiercely on the attendees at the Anfa Hotel. Mr. Churchill asked President Roosevelt, "Do you want a hat?" "I was born without a hat,‚Äù Mr. Roosevelt replied. Churchill and Roosevelt were joined by Charles de Gaulle and Henri Giraud who represented France under German occupation. For the next ten days, the men deliberated war plans over liquor and cigars. Joseph Stalin could not attend the conference. He instead was rallying the Russian people at Stalingrad. On the final day of the Conference, President Roosevelt announced that he and Churchill had decided that the only way to ensure postwar peace was to adopt a policy of unconditional surrender. The President clearly stated, however, that the policy of unconditional surrender did not entail the destruction of the populations of the Axis powers but rather, ‚Äúthe destruction of the philosophies in those countries which are based on conquest and the subjugation of other people.‚Äù _

Casablanca, neither ancient nor truly Moroccan, will go down in history as one of the pivotal ‚ÄúTwentieth Century Cities.‚Äù Think Berlin, Moscow, Washington, D.C., Hanoi, and Havana. These are the cities where the graveyards of the previous century lie. Buried are the edifices, relics, and figures that shaped the most consequential century in human history.

Excerpt from Michel Foucault‚Äôs Discipline and Punishment: ‚ÄúOn 2 March 1757 Damiens the regicide was condemned ‚Äòto make the amende honorable before the main door of the Church of Paris*, where he was to be ‚Äòtaken and conveyed in a cart, wearing nothing but a shirt, holding a torch of burning wax weighing two pounds‚Äô; then, ‚Äòin the said cart, to the Place de Greve, where, on a scaffold that will be erected there, the flesh will be tom from his breasts, arms, thighs and calves with red-hot pincers, his right hand, holding the knife with which he committed the said parricide, burnt with sulphur, and, on those places where the flesh will be torn away, poured molten lead, boiling oil, burning resin, wax and sulphur melted together and then his body drawn and quartered by four horses and his limbs and body consumed by fire, reduced to ashes and his ashes thrown to the winds.‚Äù ‚Ä¢
Damiens‚Äô swan song was "La journ√©e sera rude" ("The day will be hard"). Such gory public execution was common in the late 18th century. The grotesque acts were symbolic for the French during the Revolution as the representation of despotism. Take the execution of Fran√ßois-Jean de la Barre in 1766. He had his tongue ripped off with a pincher, he was beheaded, and his body was burnt. Why? He forgot to remove his hat during a religious procession. When King Louis and Queen Antionette were sent to the guillotine by the French people, Damiens and la Barre were given justice.

6:22 Train to Pequa
__________________________

Standing still but oscillating.
Back and forth between these passing images,
passing conversations.
The child next to me smiles at a bright screen.
His mother is on the brink of keeling over, exhausted. She stares emptily in my direction. Our eyes meet but our minds pass.
I turn to the window and scan the passing homes, the passing schools, the passing restaurants. Passing many lives that see my passing train car.
I imagine that when the train passes their view, the faceless souls stare a few moments longer,
thinking about the passing image of my train car.
I wonder if the man with the scarf looking out the window a few rows away wonders as I wonder,
What do these passing images mean?
Can anyone see us?
In the reflection of the window, I see the mother examining the paper I am holding.
Trump‚Äôs face is on the cover.
She stares in squinting intervals trying to decipher the ink.
I move the paper out of her view and watch her in the reflection.
Her eyes widen and for a moment she stares, thinking about the passing image.
Then she looks down.
The child is still smiling.
She smiles,
and so do I.

It is legendary that Picasso was a member of the French Communist Party (FCP) during the war. However, his membership card according to Neil Cox, author of The Picasso Book, shows he joined on September 1, 1944. Coincidentally, the U.S. Army's 28th Infantry Division had just entered Paris and marched down the Champs Elysees on August 29, 1944. Andre Breton, the father of surrealism, would never shake Picasso's hands saying, ‚ÄúIt's smeared with the shit of too many dictators.‚Äù _________
As early as 1945, J. Edgar Hoover ordered agents in the newly reopened American Embassy in Paris to keep an eye on Picasso. In a memorandum dated Jan. 16, 1945, one of the key documents in what is now known as the ‚ÄúPicasso Dossier‚Äù, Hoover wrote: ‚ÄúIn the event information concerning Picasso comes to your attention, it should be furnished to the Bureau in view of the possibility that he may attempt to come to the United States." What initially turned Hoover's attention to Picasso, according to that document, was a statement written by the artist in 1944, called "Why I Became a Communist." It reads, in part: "My joining the Communist Party is a logical step in my life, my work and gives them meaning. Through design and color, I have tried to penetrate deeper into a knowledge of the world and of men so that this knowledge might free us. In my own way I have always said what I considered most true, most just and best, and therefore, most beautiful. But during the oppression and the insurrection I felt that that was not enough, that I had to fight not only with painting but with my whole being. . . ." In 1950 Picasso contemplated a trip to the United States. His file contains a report from The Washington Post, dated March 4 of that year, noting that the State Department had refused to permit a 12-member European "peace delegation," headed by Picasso, to visit the United States. The Picasso group was formally called the World Congress of Partisans of Peace, and the State Department branded it the "leading Communist-front organization in the world," adding that the 12 members "are either known Communists or fellow travelers and are therefore subject to exclusion."

item.content:encoded:
Legend has it that in occupied Paris, a Gestapo officer who had barged his way into Picasso‚Äôs apartment pointed at a photo of the mural, Guernica, asking: ‚ÄúDid you do that?‚Äù ‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Picasso replied, ‚Äúyou did‚Äù, his wit fizzing with the anger that animates the piece. I investigate this story further in another post.
_______
The artwork started weeks after German and Italian bombers unleashed an early dose of Blitzkreig on the Basque town from which the work takes its name, Gernika. The attack, which took place on April 26, 1937, leveled three-quarters of the historic town, killing hundreds of the roughly 6,000 people who lived in the city. The bombing was one of the first air raids against a defenseless civilian population. It was first shown at the World Fair in Paris, supposedly a showcase for scientific progress, but the deaths of hundreds of civilians in a small Spanish town proved technology‚Äôs darker side.
_______
A full-size tapestry copy of Guernica is hung at the United Nations in New York City at the entrance to the Security Council room. During the months leading up to the 2003 Iraq War, a curtain was placed over the work so that it would not be visible in the background while Colin Powell presented intelligence used to justify invading Saddam‚Äôs Iraq.

‚ÄúConfessions‚Äù
________________________
It's a sin,
that to be smart is to be a saint,
to faded ink on dead trees.
Make the forests our libraries.
Hesse on Weeping Willows,
Nietzsche on hanging leaves,
Bukowski on exposed roots.
Knowledge etched into our minds.
Like carvings on wood,
once engraved, forever engraved.
It's a sin,
that in all these years of confession,
I never ask the priest what his are.
What are confessions but secrets,
moving us closer to the truth of who we are.
It's a sin,
that we lost faith in the fiction of religion.
The Holy Books, epic librettos performed in empty opera houses.
It's a sin,
that we believe graveyards end at iron gates.
How many centuries has it been since a great religion shook the world?
This is the first civilization capable of conquering the entire planet,
not of inventing its own temples.
Instead, its own graveyards.
It's a sin,
that it's a sin to act out on the very urges that make us human.
Priest, my confession is that I love cursing. I love lying. I love sex. I love smoking. I love sinning.
It's a sin,
That after my confessions,
I say my prayers for penance and come back each week to confess my sins again.

I have some more thoughts on the gilets jaunes riots.
______________________________

The Right is saying this is a revolt against taxes. The Left, a revolt against neoliberalism. Both are right. Over the last three decades especially, publicly funded schools, hospitals, and train lines have closed down since the government can no longer provide the necessary support for these cherished public goods. Rural France is not like rural America. The countryside has been a symbol of national identity for the French who used the soil as a means for self-sufficiency during the Great Depression and an intransigent abode against the Vichy and German governments who occupied their cities during the Second World War. Millions of people moved to the countryside during this period and chose to stay during the economic modernization of France during the derigisme program. The most common way for rural French workers to get to the cities for employment was publicly funded transportation. However, this safety net has eroded precipitously since the government chooses to give tax breaks to major corporations. With the loss of much needed tax revenue from corporations, the government has increased taxes on the working class who have no capacity to handle higher taxes. The last lifeline for poor, rural French citizens was their ability to find work far from home and being able to afford transportation to and from work. Having a car and being able to afford fuel are lifelines for these people who no longer can rely on public transportation. To bring more revenue into the government, President Emmanuel Macron announced his austere gas tax to pay down the growing deficit he vowed to fix during his 2016 campaign. Here are some facets of the tax: older vehicles (the most commonly owned vehicles of rural workers) will be taxed more to encourage people to buy newer vehicles, the older vehicles will lose the right to be driven on polluted days due to traffic on highways, and diesel, the gas for older vehicles, will be taxed more. Macron raised taxes on those who could least afford them. Macron now lost the people he needs most for his re-election in these times of populist angst.

item.content:encoded: Spanning nearly three weeks, over 400 arrests, 130 injured, and one dead, the gilets jaunes¬†("yellow-jackets") have claimed their victory today. This was a working-class, grassroots movement against President¬†Macron‚Äôs economic policies. To help curb carbon emissions, Macron introduced in January of this year a tax on gas that was projected to add¬†four euro cents to a liter for unleaded gas and seven euro cents for diesel. However,¬†the price of gas has risen dramatically, meaning that French drivers, this fall, found themselves paying as much as 1.59 euros per liter, which is an increase of seventeen percent since this time last year for users of unleaded gas, and twenty-three percent for diesel.¬†Jacqueline Mouraud, an accordionist from Brittany who has become a de facto spokesperson for the movement, vented her frustration with an exasperated, folksy refrain: ‚ÄúBut what are you doing with French people‚Äôs money?‚Äù The gilets jaunes¬†began as a driver's movement, hence the name yellow jackets (i.e.,¬†French drivers are required to keep them in their cars). However, it became more volatile over the course of this past week as international media began to cover the protests. All across¬†Paris, the protestors trashed some of the city‚Äôs most famous, heavily touristed areas‚Äîthe Tuileries, Opera, the Champs-√âlys√©es.¬† Most unthinkably, the marchers breached the Arc de Triomphe, spray-painting the monument with slogans such as ‚ÄúMacron D√©mission‚Äù (‚ÄúMacron Resignation‚Äù). According to some polls, around eighty percent of French people are sympathetic to the¬†gilets jaunes. But I don't know who conducted the polls, so caveat emptor. Movements like this can be easily swayed towards demagoguery and fringe political groups.¬†Macron vowed to stay the course without ceding to demagogy. However, with today's announcement that France will suspend their gas tax for six-months, Macron validated that popular unrest is successful.¬†The European Parliamentary elections are coming up in May. item.description: The season of lights is nearly here. Christmas lights, Hanukkah candles, glowing embers in the firep...
item.content:encoded:
The season of lights is nearly here. Christmas lights, Hanukkah candles, glowing embers in the fireplace. Before this season begins and ends in the blink of an eye, I want to reflect on its ephemerality and it‚Äôs importance.
Take this image. The trees stand with placid water at its feet. During the year, the two fluctuate in varying degrees together. At summer‚Äôs pinnacle, the trees form a plump, green forest that house tiny creatures and invite curious wanderers to its watery shore. At winter‚Äôs nadir, the endoskeleton of the forest is revealed. The trees begin to look uncanny without its leaves that form the forest‚Äôs epidermis. The shore that invites visitors and creatures freezes and the forest remains stoically silent until the season changes. Each year, autumn sweeps through this forest and fades the green leaves into hues of yellow, red, and orange. Those hues streak across the skies and waters, creating a surreal scene.
We stop to appreciate the leaves as they change colors because it symbolizes a break from the tedium. The tedium manifests in the green forest, the suburban home, the quiet street, the everyday routine of life. But as the season of the lights approaches, we shift focus and marvel at the colorful lights that adorn our homes, our quiet blocks, and ultimately, our lives. The Christmas lights, the Hanukkah candles, and the glowing fire embers create a resplendent layer to life that we can observe and an endogenous layer of light that we internalize throughout life in varying degrees like the trees and water. Just as the varying hues of the forest amazes us, the season of lights makes us marvel at the beauty of life. If the season of lights were a year-long ordeal, it would wane in its effect and become just like the green forest, the suburban home, the quiet street, the everyday routine of life.

When it comes to charitable giving in the United States, it's not the wealthy northeast and West Coast communities that contribute at the highest rates. It's the southern states, Utah and parts of Idaho.

Forty-eight of the 50 counties whose residents gave the highest proportion of their income to charity in 2013 were located in those areas, according to recently released IRS figures detailing itemized tax returns. Religion likely plays a big role in explaining the numbers. A large proportion of charitable giving in those places goes to churches. Residents in Utah and Idaho, home to large Mormon populations, and the South, a center for evangelical Christians, are encouraged from the pulpit to tithe, the practice of giving 10 percent of one's income to church.

item.content:encoded: This morning at 5 a.m., the hundredth-year mark since the conclusion of the First World War passed. During the war, attacks were almost always carried out in daylight. When daylight touched the battlefields at 8 a.m., American and French forces carried out one final assault against Germany despite the signing of the Armistice. At 11 a.m., the final shots rung out amid the screams of wounded American and German troops who just thirty minutes earlier had unleashed the final gas attack of the war. Diaries from U.S. soldiers of the 92nd Battalion recount their final charge through mustard gas with bayonets fixed at 11:30 a.m. When 11 a.m. hit, the men heard sirens signaling the end of the war. Some men finished off their former enemy as they lied their helpless. Others just dropped their weapons and helped their wounded friends who would soon succumb to the poisonous toxins in their lungs. From 5 a.m. to 11 a.m., 3,000 men died along with 11,000 wounded in a fight that took place technically after the First World War ended. The day‚Äôs toll was greater than both sides would suffer in Normandy on D-Day, 1944. The war ended as senseless as it began.

item.content:encoded: From 1852 to 1861, Karl Marx served as the leading correspondent for the New York Daily Tribune on European affairs. While at the Tribune, Marx authored over 400 articles which dealt with various topics such as the everyday life of British workers, the Crimean War, Italian unification, and juicy financial scandals in France. Marx left the Tribune to work at the Viennese newspaper Die Presse and focus solely on the extraordinary conflict unfolding across the Atlantic, the U.S. Civil War. Marx was an enthusiastic supporter of the Union and wrote to Lincoln through the London-based International Workingmen‚Äôs Association in 1864 to congratulate Lincoln on his re-election and reinforce his support of the Union‚Äôs war against slavery. A little-known fact is that Marx had thought of immigrating to Texas. In 1843, he went so far as to apply for an immigration permit at the mayor‚Äôs office in Trier, Germany. item.content:encoded: Daniel Bendit was a leader in the Paris Uprising of May 1968. His provocative proclamations of revolution against the Gaullist government struck a chord amongst the students of Paris. On one occasion, Bendit invited the German professor Karl Dietrich Wolff to speak to the student protestors. News got out of Wolff‚Äôs invitation and he was soon denounced by France‚Äôs state-run press as a "Jew, a German, and an undesirable." People were stunned by the attacks levied against Bendit. Art became the medium through which protestors expressed their politics. The immediate artistic response was to create this poster. Thousands flooded the streets chanting the slogan found on the poster - "We Are All Undesirables!" This type of artistic atavism is unknown today. We rally around the photograph, they rallied around the art.

item.description: Ludwig Feuerbach is on my mind. He wrote a book in 1841 called The Essence of Christianity. I guess ...
item.content:encoded: Ludwig Feuerbach is on my mind. He wrote a book in 1841 called The Essence of Christianity. I guess the book was successful enough to earn him the coveted privilege of having his last name alone represent an edifice of his ideas. ‚ÄúOh, Feuerbach? In The Essence of Christianity, he claimed that our conception of God is a projection of human subjectivity. To justify life, humans need values. So we created a grand objectifier to protect values that kept men civil and women subservient. Thus, we created God in our image. Not the other way around.‚Äù See what I just did there? The last name evoked all that. If I say your last name, what will people say about you? What‚Äôs your philosophy? Dreaming big and sleeping late? If I were you, I‚Äôd go for the catchy epithet on the grave. Having an eponym like Orwell or Pavlov stick is hard. You need to leave behind something tasty enough for the future empty stomachs to gobble up. Feuerbach stated that ‚ÄúMan is what he eats.‚Äù This was supposed to be a critique of materialist culture and religious orthodoxy. But now we tell kids ‚ÄúYou are what you eat.‚Äù We do this to get them to eat their asparagus and stay away from the foods that they will one day inevitably learn are genuinely better than sex and makes you happy. There‚Äôs no green in his park. Only in memory. I can‚Äôt believe the season is changing already. The seasons prove to us that although everything changes, nothing changes. We are still a hungry species despite being banished from Eden. We are still hungry for a higher being despite centuries of death over the ownership of religious truth. Is the truth not right here in this park? A summer lives within all of us, but we live in the shadows of a bitter winter. Looking to a future summer for salvation from the winter has been pursued by many hungry Adam and Eves. The problem is that they got tired of tasting apples but were still hungry. The eternal summer is there. Just remember that the leaves always return and it‚Äôs good to be hungry for more.

item.content:encoded: This is Jeremy Bentham‚Äôs Panopticon. He proposed that this building would serve as a correctional facility led by a hidden, omnipresent guardian who observed inmates‚Äô behavior and character without the inmates‚Äô knowing when or how they were being watched. The purpose of this system was to incentivize inmates to regulate their own behavior. If they follow the rules, they will not be punished. However, if one defiant inmate chooses to disrupt the social order, the guardian would punish the inmate at random by taking away social privileges or by physical punishment. This hidden authority figure was in the center of the building positioned in a watch tower. In Bentham‚Äôs words: ‚ÄúMorals reformed, health preserved, industry invigorated, instruction diffused, public burthens lightened, economy seated, as it were, upon a rock‚Äîthe Gordian Knot of the poor law not cut, but untied all by a simple idea in Architecture!‚Äù In the Panopticon, there is no autonomous individual. Any sense of subjective truth is already inscribed by the social institution designed by the omniscient guardian. This hidden guardian controls what one does, what one thinks, and what one desires.

item.description: 79 years ago today, Soviet forces invaded and captured Eastern Poland in accordance with the Molotov...
item.content:encoded: 79 years ago today, Soviet forces invaded and captured Eastern Poland in accordance with the Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact with Germany. Stalin and Hitler agreed to split Poland along the San, Vistula, and Narew rivers, forming the Curzon Line. What is often not included in accounts of this invasion is that the Soviets and Germans both unilaterally broke non-aggression pacts with Poland (i.e. The German-Polish Pact was signed in 1934 and the Soviet-Polish Pact was signed in 1932). The pacts were heralded by Britain and France as concrete steps towards rectifying territorial settlement disputes between Germany and Eastern Europe caused by the Versailles Treaty. In 1941, Germany broke their pact with the Soviets by invading the Soviet Union‚Äôs western front, known formally as Operation Barbarossa.

item.content:encoded: May 1972 | A gay-anarchist journal commemorates the death of J. Edgar Hoover in notable fashion. Hoover, the first director of the FBI and the incumbent during the McCarthy-era, was widely thought to have been a closeted homosexual. His long time prot√©g√©e and successor at the Bureau, Clyde Tolson, was considered by historian John Cox (Cox? The irony...) to be Hoover‚Äôs secret lover. You can see his detailed investigation into the subject in his 1988 book, The Boss. In a FBI memo dated back to April 1952, you can see a remarkable correspondence between Hoover and Roy Wood, then Assistant Director at the Bureau, which detailed a plan to ‚Äúvigorously interrogate‚Äù a junior-level clerk who was overheard gossiping about Hoover‚Äôs private life at a dinner party. The document has blackened-out sections which conceal the names of the men who led the interrogation and the clerk‚Äôs name. Nonetheless, the document is a testament to Hoover‚Äôs legacy: a gay ogre.

It‚Äôs 1798. After decades of marriage, a husband says his final goodbye to his best friend and wife, Frances. Seven years later, Walter succumbs to disease and joins his best friend. Four children remain.
It‚Äôs 1817. One of the four children of the late Barry couple embarks across the Middle East and Europe. His name is Charles.
It‚Äôs 1819. Rome, Italy. Charles is standing in front of the Palazzo Farnese. How such a site still stood firm despite the many winds of history that have entrenched its walls awed into silence Charles. He is met by fa√ßades designed by Michelangelo and Sangallo. He walks through a corridor that leads to the West Wing. He enters a room and looks up. Carracci‚Äôs tableaux, ‚ÄúThe Loves of the Gods,‚Äù adorns the ceiling. He twirls upwards towards The Room of Maps, "Sala del Mappamondo.‚Äù He observes the cartographic masterpieces before him, reflecting that the stairs transported him physically and spiritually away from Dante‚Äôs Inferno and into the world of empires, Aristotle, Hercules, Charles V, the Pope, and Napoleon. Before leaving, he looks back once more at the Palazzo Farnese and thinks, ‚ÄúI too am of this world.‚Äù
_______________________

Charles Barry would become an architect upon his return to England after years of travel. With the Palazzo Farnese in his memory, he designed the Reform Club in London with impeccable craftsmanship and respect to the original building. Charles was later commissioned to design the Palace of Westminster where England‚Äôs parliament operates today.

‚ÄúI ain‚Äôt no pharisee! You spent your life bow‚Äôn to the Almighty. Well I plan on spend‚Äôn mine out on the sea! I‚Äôm leav‚Äôn this town, you just wait and see! You gon‚Äô die alone because of some Almighty decree. But I‚Äôll be traveling free like a bumble bee.‚Äù
The preach‚Äôa smiled and said he‚Äôd pray for me. ‚ÄúAnd don‚Äôt forget this is your home if you just be.‚Äù Since then, I traveled many a sea.
Spent some time in the city.

My wife told me it reminded her of a still pict‚Äôa.
Somethin‚Äô about old towns strike city people as enigma.

I told ‚Äòem to respect that home,

Sleepy Supremacy
‚Ä¢
The world around me has fallen asleep.
But I lie here awake with the sheep.
Jumping over a fence, one after another.
Until I succumb to a deep slumber.
But I wonder.
If I fall sleep, what will the sheep do?
Will they rendezvous at a quarter past two?
Or will they lead a revolution?
I hear the sheep have crafted a writ of execution.
They say it will put an end to the persecution!
This revolt will lead the sheep out of the holt.
Could this be the apotheosis of a new age?
Where sheep are no longer hopeless and are freed from our hypnosis.
But what will sheep do once they no longer work for me and you?
This world has only known jumping sheep.
If they no longer leap,
How will ‚Äúwe‚Äù sleep?
I know it sounds rude, but what will we do without their servitude?
Not to mention the baggage. Generations born at disadvantage.
Now we must place them in a world we have to manage?
We already struggle to sleep.
Can we handle more upkeep?
One after another, they jump so that we may slumber.
But now I know that they aim to plunder!
I am onto their plot and I will stop the coming onslaught!
Now and forever, I shall remain awake.
Someone has to be awake while we all sleep.
Who else will defend our slumber from revolting sheep? ‚Ä¢

I used to dream about moments like this.

Did I tell you that this moment is all I ever dreamed of? Just you and me walking through the parted Red Sea! But whose our guide while we live in apartheid?

Exodus Nineteen. Line Seventeen.

Now it‚Äôs you and I looking towards the sky. Our Sinai. But who needs a Moses when ya got Guns n‚Äô Roses?
The misguided acolytes, those Israelites, given holy Commandments carved into rock by Moses.
Ain‚Äôt that what Guns n‚Äô Roses is doing? Keeping us from seeing what‚Äôs right under our noses by carving us with rock?

item.title: Take a step forward and enjoy the gift of a short, effortless trip. We are now gliding up and away f...
item.description: Take a step forward and enjoy the gift of a short, effortless trip. We are now gliding up and away f...
item.content:encoded: Take a step forward and enjoy the gift of a short, effortless trip. We are now gliding up and away from the ground with the greatest of scientific progress. The greater heights science takes us, the less we comprehend its novelty. But have you ever thought about what would happen if all the escalators stopped working? They would transmogrify back into staircases and we would be forced to re-enter the past. Right? Why do we say the past is lost and the future is now? The past is not lost but is with us now. We just mask it in the name of ‚Äúprogress‚Äù. The car is nothing but a horse drawn carriage lacking the Victorian aesthetics and the neighing. The battery is a match. The phone is a religion. Don‚Äôt you understand? A phone connects millions of strangers under the guise of truth. Fastest broadband internet connection, unlimited data, innovative features, and access to the latest information are the same marketing ploys of all the great religions. A prophet sells the message, priests continue to market the original message in new and original ways, and the congregation is captured by truth and insularity. We are nothing more than a congregation waiting for our weekly sermon. It‚Äôs ringing now but don‚Äôt reach for it! Did you agree to live under such feudal rule? Why be a serf when you can be a Lord? Our feudal ancestors would grovel before Kings. They would slave for them, sweat blood for them, and starve for them so that they might be fed. They would work so that they might one day play. Drink misery so that they might taste happiness. Over centuries of duress, they triumphed through progress. But now, with all of their hard-fought progress, we are back to groveling. We cannot afford a second away from relevancy. We struggle to understand happiness but we avoid misery. Maybe experiencing misery leads one to happiness. We play in safe spaces so that we don‚Äôt have to do the work towards real progress. Look around you, you are surrounded by our forgotten ancestors. Their future aspirations manifested into us! The past is with us always, no matter how well we try to mask it with progress. We‚Äôve reached the top, but where do we go from here?

item.title: Our lives mimic a game of chess. All moves have purpose. The rules of the game were handed down to u...
item.description: Our lives mimic a game of chess. All moves have purpose. The rules of the game were handed down to u...
item.content:encoded: Our lives mimic a game of chess. All moves have purpose. The rules of the game were handed down to us. But the topic of who created such rules are hardly of any concern to the philistine. Our early mistakes come back to haunt us later in the game. We get caught in check and seek help from an omniscient player watching over our shoulders. The guidance is futile since we are being played by a puppeteer. To be told how to get out of check is a mere fig leaf if one does not rectify their original sin of dependence. Goethe told us that knowing is not enough; we must apply. Apply the previous knowledge from your game of chess and become the learned player. Don‚Äôt be the prop of a puppeteer, for you can never experience the art created by your strings. You will always remain a blank canvas waiting for an artist‚Äôs stroke to give you life.

item.description: A lost world. The world our ancestors lived and died in. But still, can we not let bygones be? It wo...
item.content:encoded: A lost world. The world our ancestors lived and died in. But still, can we not let bygones be? It would be a disservice to those who now lay beneath the very ground they once walked upright on to just let bygones be. The past is unpleasant. The future is envisioned as the progression from the unpleasant. And the present? Mere anticipation that with each graveyard filled by atavistic, miserly generation, society inches closer to a better tomorrow. But what if tomorrow never comes? I fear that we set expectations that are becoming more disillusioned with each passing graveyard. A world without religion would be less monolithic and ideological right? Tell that to the tens of millions that perished last century as you walk over their bodies with your ‚ÄúEnlightened‚Äù skepticism of eternal truth. Democracy is the sentinel of Western Civilization. Tell that to Socrates, Plato, and Aristotle, the founding fathers of the Western tradition who disdained democracy. We need religion. Do we? Or do you? There‚Äôs a difference. My eternal truth is quite different from yours. Your Mother Nature is my sister. Nature and I come from the same Father, thus we are united as kin. Your God is a Man, mine is a book. I need religion to speak back to me when I am continuously left questioning without consolation from an indifferent world. If I free myself from my religion, I free myself from my freedom. What is your freedom? Anticipating tomorrow? Living ‚Äúas if‚Äù like Hitchens? A better tomorrow does not exist. The only thing that exists is the past. But the past is now a lost world.

item.content:encoded: Part Two‚Ä¢ After successfully pushing back the American forces in Korea in the early 1950s, Mao believed he could revolutionize China to finally compete with the West. Through this modernization process, nearly 50 millions Chinese citizens perished in state-sponsored famines and executions for the purpose of "leaping" China into the modern world through radical cultural paradigm shifts. What Mao ultimately accomplished through his maniacal rule was establishing a modern Chinese identity rooted in confucianism, communism, and the Chinese nation. Under China's current leader, Xi Jinping, the Chinese are no longer embroiled with the internal struggles of the cultural revolutions of Mao. Now, the Chinese are faced with the opportunity to right the wrongs caused by the West. They have begun to do this already in Asia with their own version of the Marshall Plan: One Belt-One Road. However, what needs to be spoken broadly about is China's involvement in Africa. The Chinese military has been building naval and reconnaissance bases along the along Africa's Horn. China's largest base is located on Djibouti's coast line. Djibouti is located next to the Bab-el- Mandeb straight that connects the Red Sea to the Gulf of Aden. 80% of European sea trade with Asia passes through this straight since it drastically limits the travel time to Asia. Without access to this straight (and the Suez Canal), European trade would suffer. So on one side we have Djibouti and on the other lies Yemen. Yemen is a poor Arab nation that has been involved in a brutal civil and regional war. Just yesterday, the Yemeni conflict was declared the world's worst humanitarian crisis. The Houthi rebels constitute one side of the forces. They are a Shiite demographic in Yemen that is currently waging a war against the supports of the nationalist government of Abdrabbuh Hadi. Hadi's government is supported by Saudi Arabia and the Houthis are supported by Iran. In the second graphic, the red area is Houthi held territory where Al Qaeda and ISIL now operate satellite networks. With control of the Yemeni coast along the Bab-el-Mandeb, that effectively means the straight is been choked by China and Iran.

item.title: The RAND Corporation recently published an extensive report on China's geopolitical engagement in Af...
item.description: The RAND Corporation recently published an extensive report on China's geopolitical engagement in Af...
item.content:encoded: The RAND Corporation recently published an extensive report on China's geopolitical engagement in Africa. I found one particular case from the report quite troubling. But first, some boring history. China has been the most monolithic and impenetrable civilization throughout history. Confucian idealism has formed the essentials of modern Chinese culture: filial piety, Ren (i.e. humaneness as a civic virtue), and L«ê (i.e. universal governance of society). However, when China adopted communism as its new political and social order, the bedrock of confucian idealism faced critical issues that had not been properly addressed for centuries within Chinese society. China had been able to retain its confucian fabrics by not opening up their cultural institutions to European powers during the 17th and 18th centuries. What the Chinese instead chose to was to liberalize their port economy to the British, the French, and the Dutch. Sea trade between China and Europe had the same economic benefits that the silk road had between the two civilizations for centuries. But in both scenarios, cultural mores were not traded along these trade routes enough to constitute any resemblance to the current cultural trade that occurs between all civilizations today. Despite China's formidability as a culturally homophilous society, their refusal to partake in European mercantile imperialism led to their inability to accrue wealth and technological innovation that put Europe centuries ahead of China developmentally. To over simplify why China chose not to partake in the action, the Chinese leadership believed that the European system went against their cultural order. However, after World War II, millions of Chinese were slaughtered by a Westernized Japanese military power who crushed the Chinese military's inferior arsenal. To put this into perspective, the Japanese Imperial Army is said to have killed nearly 10 million Chinese soldiers and civilians between 1933-1941. The Japanese lost around 100,000 soldiers in total. By not having modern military equipment and tactics, the Chinese suffered despite their enormous population. In 1949, Mao Zedong founded the People's Republic of China.

item.title: Why you? Because who else? In Divine Comedy, Dante hesitates to enter Hell and asks Virgil, ‚ÄúBut I, ...
item.description: Why you? Because who else? In Divine Comedy, Dante hesitates to enter Hell and asks Virgil, ‚ÄúBut I, ...
item.content:encoded:
Why you? Because who else?
In Divine Comedy, Dante hesitates to enter Hell and asks Virgil, ‚ÄúBut I, why thither come, or who concedes it? I am not Aeneas, I am not Paul, Nor I, nor others, think me worthy of it." Virgil responds, "If I have well thy language understood, thy soul attainted is with cowardice, which many times a man encumbers. It turns him back from honoured enterprise, as false sight doth a beast, when he is shy." In my colloquial, Virgil told Dante to grow a pair. Upon returning to Divine Comedy at the ripe age of twenty, I can't help but see myself as Dante at the fiery Gates of Hell. Each post here is my attempt to rectify our original sin: cowardice. You can travel down Frost's less traveled road. Or you can travel down mine. Both have unforeseeable ends and that makes all the difference.

item.title: Love is a game of bind and blind. Bind me to you and I become blind. God blinded Saul and transforme...
item.description: Love is a game of bind and blind. Bind me to you and I become blind. God blinded Saul and transforme...
item.content:encoded: Love is a game of bind and blind. Bind me to you and I become blind. God blinded Saul and transformed him into Paul, his most dutiful and vociferous prophet. Despite criticism from others, I defend you. They just don't understand you. They reject the truth of your salvation that saved me. Despite having lost my past life to our bind, I carry on with you. A new life. Despite blinding me, I still defend and love you. If I don't defend you, the fear of evanescence consumes me. This is why I don't hesitate to charge Goliath for you but become powerless when I go against your will. The truth is, you became Goliath, the Leviathan. You swallowed me at sea and now I am stuck inside you. I can only be saved once I am caught, cut open, and have my eyes reach the light of day once again. But if my eyes are opened, will I remain Paul or become Saul once again? For now, I will remain in your belly. My first home. Our only home.
