item.title: George Orwell once said, "To see what is in front of one‚Äôs nose is a constant struggle." This is a t...
item.description: George Orwell once said, "To see what is in front of one‚Äôs nose is a constant struggle." This is a t...
item.content:encoded: George Orwell once said, "To see what is in front of one‚Äôs nose is a constant struggle." This is a tricky metaphor. A metaphor should not have to be dissected like a frog in order to decipher its meaning. For example, "time slips through one's hands like sand" connects the abstract nature of time to a physical experience that we can all relate to. Orwell's metaphor however is not so discernible because it tackles the phenomena of immediacy. We are permanent bodies in a changing world. Especially nowadays where the news-cycle warps reality into an endless change of events instead of a contemporary state. I chose Rene Magritte's "The Son of Man" and Edward Hopper's "Boy and the Moon" since both capture Orwell's metaphor well. Magritte intended for his work to be his only self-portrait. This struck a nerve in me. Where's his face? Of course a face exists behind the apple. We know this because we see faces constantly. However, what we really want is to see behind a face. Especially an attractive one. We want to believe that there's always more than what meets the eye. This is our mechanism for attributing admirable qualities of others to our malleable brains. The observer is drawn towards the man and tries to use our mechanism to ascribe a meaning. But there is no face and thus, no eyes for us to look into. The Son of Man, Magritte himself, you and I, are forced to stand staring at the emptiness of a face while the true grounding of the world, the texture of the rock and the beauty of the ocean and sky are left behind and forgotten. What is in front of his nose is the apple. But in front of ours is a whole scene that we can't seem to fixate our attention to. Hopper forces us in "Boy and the Moon" to look at a scene with no face. The moon is like an eye in the sky looking with us. Not through us. The moon's eye does not judge us but invites us to ponder and reflect. However, the eyes of society immediately judge. This is why we put apples in front of our face. We choose apples based on their appearance. They're tasty for a few bites. But once one nears the pit, the apple loses its allure and is cast aside. Let one reach your pit and if they stay, keep them.

item.title: Part One‚Ä¢ In Dostoevsky‚Äôs final work, The Brothers Karamazov, a father neglected his first-born chil...
item.description: Part One‚Ä¢ In Dostoevsky‚Äôs final work, The Brothers Karamazov, a father neglected his first-born chil...
item.content:encoded: Part One‚Ä¢ In Dostoevsky‚Äôs final work, The Brothers Karamazov, a father neglected his first-born child. Their names aren‚Äôt necessarily important because you won‚Äôt remember them anyway. It‚Äôs pretty understandable why we don‚Äôt remember names. It‚Äôs a cost-benefit analysis at the end of the day. But isn‚Äôt that sad? Dostoevsky understood names were not important because names are pat. A name is used to make dogs appear less as feces-eating creatures that lick their own crotches and more like members of the family. I digress. The father‚Äôs negligence towards his son was not rooted in any ulterior motive. He simply just forgot about him. He was too busy becoming a regular of Parisian brothels and joining the noble French workers of the February revolution in Paris to remember he had a one-year-old child at home. So noble. We can forget about our natural priorities when the allure of vices and adventure appear invariably better than reality. It‚Äôs worth noting that Dostoevsky chose a brothel and the French revolutions of 1848 as the two main abodes for the father. The brothel is nature‚Äôs den. The halfway house where men unwittingly vegetate in the only place that keeps the world at bay. If women banded together and chose the male path, the world would turn into one huge brothel.

item.title: Part Two‚Ä¢ Then, the workers‚Äô revolutions of 1848. The father took place in the revolution and is sai...
item.description: Part Two‚Ä¢ Then, the workers‚Äô revolutions of 1848. The father took place in the revolution and is sai...
item.content:encoded: Part Two‚Ä¢ Then, the workers‚Äô revolutions of 1848. The father took place in the revolution and is said to have met the famous Russian anarchist Mikhail Bakunin while in Paris. The February revolution ultimately failed since the French tradesmen felt their alliance with the petty bourgeois was fruitless. Bakunin arrived in Paris in 1848 after word spread across Europe that the socialist project was going to be firmly planted in French soil. Deeply influenced by Hegelian dialectics and allied with Karl Marx, Bakunin decried the crimes of the Russian Empire against the Polish people. His views landed him in prison where he would spend the majority of his adult years ridden with disease and destitution. Despite his morbid final years, his anarchist idealism spread famously to Spain in the 1930s where the only anarchist insurrection against an incumbent government ever took place in the Western world. The father, the workers of Paris, and Bakunin had one thing in common: they lived ‚Äúas if.‚Äù

item.title: Part Three‚Ä¢ Living ‚Äúas if‚Äù is anarchical. It's individualism. If you think about it, the individuali...
item.description: Part Three‚Ä¢ Living ‚Äúas if‚Äù is anarchical. It's individualism. If you think about it, the individuali...
item.content:encoded: Part Three‚Ä¢ Living ‚Äúas if‚Äù is anarchical. It's individualism. If you think about it, the individualist‚Äôs maxim is ‚ÄúLive life full of satire.‚Äù Rosa Parks lived as if a black woman could sit in the front of the bus in Jim Crow America. The father lived as if he did not have to take care of his child despite that being his principal role in nature. I write as if anyone will read a three-part series on individualism and anarchy. The individual purposely acts outside of the normative boundaries of his or her society to make a point. We do not cater to the needs of anyone besides ourselves. The community, the Gemeinda, exists within the commune: you. Whether or not you agree with their philosophy or their work, they are the true anarchists. Individuals. This type has many names: original, anarchist, revolutionary, hero. But I like sophomoric. Only a fool could believe they can disrupt the social order. But wisdom comes through experience, a maxim Hermann Hesse taught me in his work Siddhartha: "Wisdom is not communicable. The wisdom which a wise man tries to communicate always sounds foolish. Knowledge can be conveyed, but not wisdom. It can be found, it can be lived, it is possible to be carried by it, miracles can be performed with it, but it cannot be expressed in words and taught." Parks was a hero. Bakunin was an anarchist. The father was sophomoric. Where you and I fit in will only be determined by time.

item.title: I can't stop thinking about this figure I saw yesterday in the news. Since 9/11, 6,940 soldiers have...
item.description: I can't stop thinking about this figure I saw yesterday in the news. Since 9/11, 6,940 soldiers have...
item.content:encoded:
I can't stop thinking about this figure I saw yesterday in the news. Since 9/11, 6,940 soldiers have died in war. The death count should be 13,880. 6,940 young men and women who lost the lives they were living and the lives they were going to live.
George Orwell, upon his return from his service overseas in the British Imperial Police, began his career as a writer. Orwell witnessed the hanging of a young man in Burma, which he recounted in "A Hanging": "It is curious, but till that moment I had never realised what it means to destroy a healthy, conscious man. When I saw the prisoner step aside to avoid the puddle I saw the mystery, the unspeakable wrongness, of cutting a life short when it is in full tide. This man was not dying, he was alive just as we are alive." The mind can process conflict. It has been been present throughout our history. Our society, however, can not. It seems paradoxical because societies are made up of a collective mind. But society is civilized. We are not. The tabula rasa we are allegedly all born with is domesticated by the societal structures that makes one civilized. A glass of merlot in a red cup is not civilized. Wearing jeans to a funeral is not civilized. Says who? Society. Murder is not civilized. Soldiers kill or murder, depending on one's opinion of a soldier's purpose. The wars we currently fight are not wars. They are fantasies. The only time foreign wars reach our shores is when a terrorist attacks our society. Besides that, we live normal lives removed from the horrors of war. When the solider returns home, he is no longer a persona grata. He has come back to live his second life but finds that he is a stranger in his homeland. Alone in the arms of loved ones. Alone trying to become civilized once again. How can you close your eyes once they've been opened to the truth of our nature?

item.title: There's a French chapel that comes to my mind. It was abandoned but for some reason it still felt al...
item.description: There's a French chapel that comes to my mind. It was abandoned but for some reason it still felt al...
item.content:encoded: There's a French chapel that comes to my mind. It was abandoned but for some reason it still felt alive. Maybe it was the light. But upon reflection, what illuminated the chapel was the corporeal nature of my visit. The chapel was me. A masterpiece left to ruin in a world of masterpieces. What was once a chapel for refuge and purpose is now an empty sanctuary for lost souls. I began to question why it is that we're mortal. Our story, our mortality, has already been spoiled: we die in the end. However, that's not what bothered me. What bothered me was what kind of story will I leave behind once l pass. The story I want is the story of that French chapel. Built with many hands. Beautiful, inside and out. Whose core is spiritual and whose skin is human. And despite being forgotten by the world, it will come to life in the heart and mind of the lost soul who enters my abandoned chapel.

item.title: ‚Ä¢Ersatz (The Substitute), written by Rudolf Sremec, is an animated film with a simple plot. A man go...
item.description: ‚Ä¢Ersatz (The Substitute), written by Rudolf Sremec, is an animated film with a simple plot. A man go...
item.content:encoded:
‚Ä¢Ersatz (The Substitute), written by Rudolf Sremec, is an animated film with a simple plot. A man goes to the beach and everything he brings is inflatable. However, the film's message is not so simple.
Ersatz translates to "substitute." It's historical etymology is noteworthy. In World War I, the Ersatz Corps was a division used by the Germans to break down enemy defense lines. The Corps was home to the most inexperienced soldiers, who evidently were the youngest and newest recruits usually between the ages of 16 and 20. Most young men would die within the first month of deployment. Their remains rarely made it back home, since their bodies were far too disfigured to discern who they were. Families were told they died valiantly in battle, but we know their deaths suggests some lives are deemed less valuable. Replaceable. Soldiers were told to stomp over their remains and press on. The film All Quiet on the Western Front captured the short lives of the young German boys of the Ersatz Corps. During World War II, British soldiers found German ersatz goods such as "Ersatzkaffee" which is what we would consider instant coffee. When the British returned home, they began to use ersatz to describe goods that were a substitute form of a superior or more popular good.
Back to the film. Each character was drawn with simple geometric shapes which I believe Sremec purposefully did to represent the clash between Cubist neoclassicism and the popular Dadaist and deconstruction movements after World War I. The man used the ersatz versions of common items one brings to the beach. Thus, our cube man rejected artifice for utilitarian use. Dadaism rejected traditional art forms for original artwork that embraced anti-bourgeois rationality over conservative irrationality which turned young boys into ersatz goods. Replaceable and inherently meaningless.
If you think of it, we use social media as an ersatz version of real social interaction. We wear ersatz clothing to project an external appearance that does not reflect our inner selves. The man in the film valued reality over artifice.

Take 10 minutes and check out this little film.

item.description: Part Two‚Ä¢ What Marx could not have possibly witnessed, since he passed away in 1883, was capitalism...
item.content:encoded:
Part Two‚Ä¢
What Marx could not have possibly witnessed, since he passed away in 1883, was capitalism's reform and ultimate fruitfulness. With anti-trust laws, minimum wage (which is detestable and needs reform), and worker's rights enshrined and protected by the Square and New Deal legacies, workers have never been more unbounded to the state bureaucracy. Entrepreneurs have created and amassed wealth by the billions under capitalism. Artisans, whose skills became unmarketable in the Industrial Age, now use modern technology created under the umbrella of capitalism to sell and create their work to a global market. Therefore, to use Marx's name as a nomme de guerre in the fight against capitalism is ultimately fruitless. Marx was a man of his time and his contribution to the world should not be trivialized. We can still read Plato, with pleasure and profit, as an intellectual discipline, for training in rhetoric and argument, as the founding voice of Western philosophy, and for insights into the culture of ancient Greece; but in doing so we do not need to believe that the table on which we write is merely an imperfect representation of the idea of the perfect table that exists in a purely spiritual realm somewhere else. Marx will no doubt continue to be read and written about for much the same reasons.

item.content:encoded:
Part One‚Ä¢

Karl Marx turned 200 years old two days ago and yet, his eponymous legacy still lives. The Soviet Union, the graveyard of communism, as Afghanistan is the graveyard of empires, collapsed 27 years ago but still evokes revolutionary bravado among the fiercest Starbucks Trotskyists and woefulness among our classroom Che‚Äôs. Marx and the Soviet Union will not retreat from the forefront of political, economic, and social discussion because without the two, we may not be having the discussion at all. I‚Äôve written previously that this century will be defined by our search for the next author who will rewrite history to reflect the present and lead humanity into its next chapter. Thus far, Karl Marx has told the best story, and this saddens me. Marx was a man of his time, as we all are. Marx‚Äôs vision of Europe was dark and rightfully so, but his vision of the future aimed backwards. Marx‚Äôs magnum opus, Capital, when boiled down to my simpler synopsis, is a story that both anachronistic and timeless in its condemnations of capitalism. Two timeless critiques was on the free market economy since its structures are easily manipulated where wealth accrues in the hands of the few and that humans nature‚Äôs relentless greed for profit would lead to overproduction of goods by mechanising the workplace and squeezing the wage of the workers. Although Marx‚Äôs critiques are quite valid and only an ideological fool would disagree on these outcomes, only an ideological fool would maintain that these critiques are relevant today as they were then. Marx's theory on economics, when paralleled to the context of his day, I believe drew heavily from European industrialization in the first half of the nineteenth century and which led to the untenable development of an unskilled labor force, quantity over quality production, and mass consumerism.

item.description: Edward Hopper's "Excursion into Philosophy" (1950) We have a man and woman. He is grey and urbane. S...
item.content:encoded:
Edward Hopper's "Excursion into Philosophy" (1950)
We have a man and woman. He is grey and urbane. She is young and insouciant. He has read a book of philosophy and is now fixated on the light. The book's effect on him is palpable. His eyes are looking at the light while most of his body is stuck in the shadows. He lives in the shadows and wonders why the world is so dark.
He may be getting closer to the light, the truth. Or maybe he got to the light but realized he was too late. The concrete meaning he created out of the the abstractions of life now seem pointless and don't make sense. He asks himself, "What if I had stayed? Would things have been better than they are now?" He wishes he can go back to the day he chose to live another life other his own. We do this often. Why live our lives when it leaves you like him. Alone with only his thoughts, he stares and waits. "Ce grand malheur, de ne pouvoir √™tre seul" "This great misfortune, of not being able to be alone."

item.content:encoded:
In 1963, Edmund Gettier published "Is Justified True Belief Knowledge?", which challenged the necessary and sufficient conditions people used to justify their beliefs on knowledge. In the paper, Gettier described the flawed reasoning within the argument of known knowledge and knowledge of belief with the famous "(f) John owns a Ford" case. John owns a Ford because I, the viewer, saw him drive by in it on multiple occasions. However, the flawed reasoning in the proposition is that my conclusion that John owns a Ford was based only on previous knowledge that led to my present belief. It could be that John was always seen driving a Ford but it was his wife's car; thus, John doesn't own a Ford. Or, the conclusion that John owned a Ford was drawn only because John had the keys to a Ford in his hand and said he owned it. I believed him because why the hell not? He seemed nice. However, could it be that John found the keys on the floor one day and because he was a life-long kleptomaniac, he actually found the Ford and stole it? It's most likely not true but it's also just as likely to be true since I will never truly know how he got the car despite all evidence presented to me since I can not fathom John's intentions and intuitions.
Humans operate on systems of beliefs that construct one's knowledge. Thus, knowledge is rooted in belief and is inherently subjective.

item.title: Part Two: From 1600 to 1900, empires spread global immanence while nationalistic consciousness brew...
item.description: Part Two: From 1600 to 1900, empires spread global immanence while nationalistic consciousness brew...
item.content:encoded:
Part Two:
From 1600 to 1900, empires spread global immanence while nationalistic consciousness brewed within their own de facto borders as peasants and owners began their centuries-long feud in forming the modern capitalist-nation state system. However, those three centuries also began to increasingly see the emerging Western individual who valued liberty and freedom of religion, property, and politics.
From 1900 to the present, humanity has now moved on from creating God in their image and now chooses to create ideas in their image. Two world wars that left over 100 million dead and an invisible war that demolished sovereignty, challenged morality, and ended history as Fukuyama put it, the present times are forcing many to look backwards because Age of Faith and Exploration has left many of us in the Age of Meaning. Duchamp's submission to the Society of Independent Artists in 1917, "Fountain," pictured here captures this new Age of Meaning perfectly. Is this a urinal or fountain? Duchamp posed this question to capture the essence of what art should return to: subjective meaning.
Duchamp was influenced by Romantic artists from the 18th century who produced work purely for representing art as an abstract product of the mind and not a institutionalized product for the state.
The sea was once the arena for humanity to find themselves but has now increasingly become a place where we look for ourselves. We are trapped by all and bounded by nothing, and this is why art is our escape and our context. Ronald Barthes declared the author's death, the individual, just as Nietzsche declared mankind's first author's death in 1882: God. Now we are author-less and this age will be our journey of finding our next author.

Part One:
Orwell called art propaganda. Picasso called art theft. I call art context.
If you remember back to my last post, I stressed the importance of art as a visual aid to historians who wish to write history journalistically or as a story. In this post, I want to further explore this idea by telling a narrative of history thus far with five paintings: Rembrandt‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Storm at the Sea of Galilee,‚Äù Leutze‚Äôs ‚ÄúWashington Crossing the Delaware,‚Äù Friedrich‚Äôs ‚ÄúWanderer Above the Sea of Fog,‚Äù and Bartlett‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Watercolorist.‚Äù
Up until the 20th century, art has served primarily for two purposes: to glorify religion and the state. The glorification of religion in art began after the fall of Rome in the fifth century which plunged Western Europe into a period Petrarch characterized best as the cultural darkness that filled in the absence of Rome as the metropole of the world. Medieval Europe reified religion rather superciliously to adhere to Augustine‚Äôs message to purify oneself for the City of God while trapped in the City of Man. Throughout the Medieval Ages, ca. 500-1500, magnificent artwork with Jesus being coronated as the center of the triptych in Eastern European Christian art and as the child of God who symbolized Western Europe‚Äôs rebirth after Rome‚Äôs collapse. The Holy Roman Emperor and all preceding and successive monarchs during this period embraced a divine right to sovereignty which was bestowed to God first and then to the King and the Pope who served as incumbent divinities while God ‚Äúspoke‚Äù to them.
However, once the Age of Exploration began, the Age of Faith ceased as explorers ventured into far flung lands and encountered new topographies, new cultures, and new freedoms that the heavily Christianized Europe evidently lacked. The Age of Exploration, the Modern period (ca. 1500-1900) began an untenable movement against the axioms of religion and state that Martin Luther and the printing press brought to unimaginable depths. I think of this period as time in which God ceased to create Man in his image and Man began to create God in their image.

item.title: I always appreciate a historian who rejects the conventional boundaries of historiography and depict...
item.description: I always appreciate a historian who rejects the conventional boundaries of historiography and depict...
item.content:encoded:
I always appreciate a historian who rejects the conventional boundaries of historiography and depicts history as a Greek epic rather than an expose work.
I've been oddly struck by the importance of paintings and history recently. Take these two for example: one is a painting of the Parthenon in classical Greece and the other is photograph of the Parthenon as it stands today. Really pay attention to the details and think about how each made you feel about the focus of the works: the Parthenon.
Nietzsche wrote that all philosophy had fallen forfeit to history. I'd like to add that all history has fallen forfeit to reality. The Parthenon of today is a synecdoche of the classical period. The Parthenon of the past was Western Civilization's greatest metropole. It's not so important that classical Greece existed, because one can argue that it never existed. Were you there when Pericles delivered his Funeral Oration? Were you there when Plato's Academy opened? No, and this removes you from the a posteriori experience that Kant said leads one to pure reason. The only important takeaway from studying the history of classical Greece is that you can have faith in its existence. Without faith, reality supercedes and history falls victim to the relativism of an a posteriori outlook of the world.
My faith in the historical importance of the Parthenon is restored in paintings like this. This painting will forever capture the history of classical Greece and my faith in it's existence.

item.content:encoded:
Juan Antonio Ribera, Cincinnatus Leaves the Plough to Dictate Laws to Rome (1806)

In Book I of Machiavelli's, Discourses on Livy, there is a section of his lamentations on the Italian Renaissance that is worth exploring.

In Discourses, Machiavelli was perplexed with the Italian's negligence of ancient politics during the Italian Renaissance. While Italians revived and re-applied Greco-Roman architecture, law, and logic to their society, they anathematized Greco-Roman politics for its crude, antediluvian nature. Italian's believed that political absolutism, nepotism, and major European wars were byproducts of Greco-Roman politics. The solution to Europe's political and social turmoil of the 14th and 15th centuries was to have governments disenfranchise old ideologies of politics and economics and create new ones like capitalism & mercantilism, both of which were harbingers of the Great Divergence.
Machiavelli instead saw Greco-Roman politics as a transcendent and fundamental guide to leading city-states. His most famous work, The Prince, served as the antithesis to the political revisionism of the Renaissance period which he believed was creating a new generation of leaders who lacked civic leadership. In his work, Machiavelli chose a leader who he revered as the model of civic leadership, Lucius Quinctius Cincinnatus, or Cincinnatus.
Cincinnatus was a Roman statesman who, in his old age, retired to go work on his small farm. However, his retirement would be cut short when Rome was attacked by a tribe called the Aequi, who destroyed a Roman army sent to stop them. Senators came to Cincinnatus and asked him to assume the role of Dictator to lead Rome against the Aequi. Cincinnatus humbly accepted, leading an army to soundly defeat the Aequi and stop the threat. Now, as Dictator, he acted to first disband his army and then relinquish his absolute control, electing to return to his farm. He would assume this role once more when a wealthy Roman declared himself King and threatened the Republic. Both times he assumed power, reclaimed stability, and gave back the power to the Roman people.
We should not forget Cincinnatus.

item.title: When's the last time you had an adventure? An adventure to me is not planned. It just unfolds as you...
item.description: When's the last time you had an adventure? An adventure to me is not planned. It just unfolds as you...
item.content:encoded:
When's the last time you had an adventure?
An adventure to me is not planned. It just unfolds as you go. Driving with no where to go and hopping out of your car in a foreign place is adventurous. Walking the city streets you've walked a thousand times with a plan is not really adventurous. Hopping off the subway at a random stop or hopping in a taxi and getting out at any random point is adventurous. Walking into a store that you would never think about going into and looking around is adventurous.
What I am getting at here is that spontaneity is absent in our society. We go from A to B to C and that's it. The thought of going from A to Z is absurd!
Okay, so what's the plan when we get there? Why does there need to be a plan when life is so unpredictable?
I can't tell you what will happen five minutes from now or 5 years from now. Your life can completely change in seconds, so are you really content with the way your life is going now?
Why don't you switch it up and do something you are not used to. Go to a nature preserve and walk around. Go to the local train station and hop on and get off somewhere you've never been before. Say hi to more strangers. Read a book. Get in a fight. Tell someone you love them. Whatever floats your boat.
Life is unpredictable, so do something that people would hear and say, "Wait, what? You did that?" Stop being so fucking boring is what I'm saying! Your life is just a story in the end... make it a good one.

item.content:encoded:
Zdzis≈Çaw Beksi≈Ñski drew some dark shit.
His artwork reminds me of some type of dystopian world where humanity is at war with evil. His other works show burning cities with demons and skeletons, abandoned homes, and anachronistic placements of modern infrastructures in a dismal world. Here, we have a lone traveler who is looking for something. You can decide what he's looking for, but it's clear that he is surrounded by death.
Aren't we all lone travelers surrounded by death? Death is above the traveler, not eye to eye. Death always looms over us even when we can't see it. I like to think that the statue in the back is holding the clock that is counting down the traveler's life until his final breath.
I think we are all at war with death. We have to fight to keep on going physically and mentally because when we begin to give up the fight, we already welcome in death.
I relate to this little dude in some weird way and that's why I love art.

item.title: Writers have captured the essence of nature all throughout our written history. When we are not able...
item.description: Writers have captured the essence of nature all throughout our written history. When we are not able...
item.content:encoded:
Writers have captured the essence of nature all throughout our written history. When we are not able to see rocky rivers, sprawling fields full of vegetation or flowers, or just a humongous mountain that nearly touches the clouds, we rely on sentences that beautifully capture those pictures for us.This past weekend, I went to Vermont and was able to see all of the images I just described in person and I had many of my nerdy, "who the hell thinks of this shit," kind of moments.
While driving on route 30, which runs parallel to the river in the picture, I saw a sign for a town called Jamaica that said it was founded in the 1700's. While driving through the town I thought of how crazy it is that I'm driving a car, listening to satellite radio and people used to ride horses for transportation and sing songs when they wanted to listen to music.
Then the Romans came to my mind. We think of the Romans as these demagogues of the ancient world (and the Greeks) and it's almost like we forget these people looked at the same sun and moon we look at. What blows my mind is that the Romans look at the Egyptians how we look at the Romans. One day, people will look at us the same way we look at the Romans.
What's going to make us so much more complex than any other civilization that historians have ever studied is that there are no gaps in humanity now.
The Fertile Crescent was where shit went down in the ancient world. The gap in humanity during this time is that we had no idea what humans were doing during this time period in other parts of the world. Now, everywhere is like the Fertile Crescent. We have an almost entirely connected world. Technologically through social media, geopolitically from politics, and geographically from science.

With all the innovation and progress humanity has achieved so far, we forget about nature. Transcendentalists wanted to bring nature back into our lives after decades of industrial revolution. The poet William Wordsworth wanted us to know that materialism takes us away from nature. And now here I am, a nobody, living in 2016, writing this on a smartphone.

Nature is cool. You should check it out.

item.content:encoded:
Oakland, CA. December 8th, 1941. On the day after Pearl Harbor, a Japanese shop owner hung the sign "I AM AN AMERICAN" in the window of his store. A year later, his store was shut down and sold due to Roosevelt's Order 9066 that allowed the physical removal of all Japanese Americans into internment camps by the US government.
At the time, the public saw this Order fit for the time period. But looking back now, many consider this event to be one of America's darkest moments. If you scratch a liberal, a fascist will bleed. Well isn't that the truth. Fear brings out the worst in humanity.
Do I think Roosevelt was wrong for rounding up the Japanese? No, because if I was an 18 year old in 1941, I would have most likely supported this because nationalism was through the roof. In 2016, the thought of violating any group of people's human rights like this troubles me and I would publicly denounce it.
A cool side note, 14,000 Japanese Americans were selected from the camps they were put into and formed most of the 442nd Infantry Division. They became the most decorated division in American military history. They earned 9486 Purple Hearts, 8 Presidential Unit Citations, and 21 Medal of Honors.

item.content:encoded:
I woke up early one morning and was wide awake and instead of going back to bed, I decided to watch the sunrise. Keep in mind: I am NOT a morning person.
I snapped this picture along with a few others that were just as beautiful. I was by myself on the beach for a little while until an old man came along. The old man stripped down to his bathing suit at around 7 a.m. and dove into the water. He swam the beach for a good 30-45 minutes and then got out, dried off, and then left. That was it. No one was there to see him except me.I'll always remember the old man swimming early in the morning because I would've never seen him if I went back to bed.
Sometimes when you wake up early and feel awake, don't lie around and do nothing. Switch it up and go outside and experience a sunrise by yourself.
